speakerposition: topic
subtopic
Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Terry Fox Achievement Award honours an individual or group that best exemplifies the spirit, dedication and determination for which Terry Fox will always be remembered.
Tonight this national award is being presented to Joey Saccary, a grade 12 student from Glace Bay High School, a victim of spina bifida.
Joey has been active at Glace Bay High with the Circle of Friends and is the founder of the Disability Awareness Group.
He is a volunteer with the IWK Telethon and a camp for disabled children. He was a member of the first Youth Focus Group sponsored by the Nova Scotia Youth Secretariat.
Joey has served on the University College of Cape Breton task force on problems pertaining to the disabled and has worked with the Department of Tourism in studying accessibility of buildings for those who are blind or wheelchair bound. He is a member of the Spina Bifida Society and The Wheelchair Sports Association.
Mr. Speaker, I want to express through you to him how proud I am of this courageous and determined young Canadian. Congratulations, Joey.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to commend the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and his colleague in Newfoundland for their responsible and forthright conservation decision announced last week to close commercial salmon fishing in Newfoundland.
This virtually completes the closure of commercial salmon harvesting throughout Atlantic Canada, except for Labrador, following earlier bans in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia over past years. This recent decision must be recognized as a particularly difficult one in view of the cod tragedy now being experienced in Newfoundland waters. Therefore, the accompanying joint government proposal to purchase salmon licences for permanent retirement is both a compassionate shortterm measure to provide relief to the financial burdens of many fishermen, as well as a sound long-term investment in the conservation of the Atlantic salmon resource. Slowly but surely we all are learning the hard lessons about conservation in Canada. The Atlantic salmon will ever be an important symbol of our environmental mission. Let us ensure that we build that resource on the moves now made and that we permit no other challenge to impair its conservation.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was disappointed yesterday when I heard the Minister of National Defence criticize the three-party report on a renewed Canadian Constitution. The Prime Minister of Canada supported the report in Quebec, but where are the other 12 cabinet ministers from that province? Who speaks for a renewed Canada in Quebec? It is high time the other 12 spoke up as well.

March 11, 1992

It is important since we have 12 ministers from the province of Quebec who sit in this federal cabinet that they go to the province of Quebec and speak in favour of a renewed Canada. So far the only person who has done that from the government across the way has been the Prime Minister, who has gone out and said "yes" to the report of the three political parties. That is important, but it is important also that the other 12 ministers do the same.
I ask this question: Who speaks for Canada? Who speaks for a renewed Canada in the province of Quebec? It is important that the 12 ministers get out there and sell this idea of a renewed Canada that we talk about in our report to the people in the province of Quebec. It is important that they do so.
Mr. Speaker, I ask this: Who besides the Prime Minister is speaking for a renewed Canada in the province of Quebec?

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this Saturday marks Shabbat Zachor, a sabbath set aside by Jews around the world to remember the plight of all oppressed Jews.
I believe very strongly that we must remember the struggles of the people who face daily discrimination because they are Jewish. Syrian Jews are in this intolerable situation.
It was at this time in 1974 that four young Syrian women were caught trying to escape Syria into Lebanon. Their raped and mutilated bodies were dumped in sacks in front of their parents' Damascus homes.
Jewish students from across Canada will be on Parliament Hill tomorrow lobbying to make us aware of the terrible plight of Syrian Jews.
We must support them and work together to ensure that Syrian officials stop this persecution. Syrian Jews
must no longer be denied important and basic human rights.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the Minister of Finance announced the winding down of the Veterans Land Administration's recent budget, he caused a great deal of grief to the employees of this agency by the manner in which the elimination of the agency was announced. At the time no clear path was announced for the future of the agency or its employees. Other employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs are also wondering what the future holds for them.
I call on the Minister of Veterans Affairs to assure the employees, both of VLA and other sections of the Veterans Affairs portfolio, at the earliest possible time that there will be no staff cuts in this department.
I want the minister to also assure the House that he is not planning to shuffle departmental positions around the country to satisfy short-term political gain. The people in this department deserve to know what the future holds for them. The veterans of Canada also deserve to know that the high level of service to which they have become accustomed since the end of the wars will continue.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Chatelaine magazine recently chose Truro, Nova Scotia, as one of the 10 best communities in Canada in which to live. Truro was selected based on being one of the safest, most affordable, most neighbourly towns. I would like to add that Truro is also innovative, positive, generous and independent.
Currently Thiro groups are working on economic development projects, environmental projects, and immigration projects that are unique for all of Canada.
During the application period for the Atlantic women's prison, Truro groups came together and developed a very comprehensive application involving many sectors of the community. Even now, after the decision to locate
March 11, 1992

the prison in Truro has been made, the community is determined to make it the best in the country.
Chatelaine's endorsement of Truro was well earned and Truro and its people should be proud of their community.

speakerposition: subtopic
subtopic: CANADIAN CENTRE FOR OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
CANADIAN CENTRE FOR OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, would you spend $8 million a year to help save $20 billion? Apparently this government will not. I am referring specifically to the Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety.
The centre, as you know, is a model organization in that it exemplifies the spirit of co-operation that can exist between government, labour and business. All three share in its administration.
It has in its mandate the promotion of health and safety and disease control in the workplace. It is a Canadian success story that is world renowned for its objective research and it provides useful information to all segments of society.
Indeed, of its total sales, 43 per cent of them were to foreign markets. Yet this government is threatening to shut it down by calling off its funding.
This government likes to talk about productivity, competitiveness and the need for co-operation but does very little about it. Here we have a centre the work of which helps to prevent over $20 billion a year in lost productivity to the economy for a nominal cost of $8 million, and declining.
With the spiralling costs of health care, it makes sense to take preventive measures through education and information campaigns. If anything, perhaps the government could use the centre to help correct its shortsightedness.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to draw the attention of Quebecers to highlights of the 1992 federal budget. The reduction in the personal income surtax will benefit 4.7 million taxpayers in Quebec.
We are going to simplify, streamline and enhance federal support for 2.9 million families and 2.3 million children in Quebec.
The negative aspects of the present tax system for the average family will be eliminated.
We will make it easier for people to own their own homes by allowing families in Quebec to use funds invested in their RRSPS.
We will reduce the tax burden on 11,000 Quebec companies in the manufacturing and processing sectors; we will increase the capital cost allowance rate for machinery in those sectors; and further measures are planned to assist small businesses and farming operations in Quebec.
We will improve assistance for some 42,000 disabled persons in Quebec.
And finally, Mr. Speaker, we will provide additional assistance for about 170,000 students at the post-secondary level in the province.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today Denison Mines is shutting down its mining operations in Elliot Lake, Ontario, resulting in the loss of some 1,000 jobs.
The number of jobs lost during the last two years is over 3,400 or 85 per cent of the mining jobs in that community. One cannot exaggerate the adverse impact these lay-offs will have on the community in terms of loss of competence in the future and loss of hope that new employment can be found for these workers.
Making things even worse, the government has announced it is closing the Atomic Energy Control Board office in Elliot Lake at a time when it should be expanding its operation to ensure that the decommissioning of these uranium mines is done in a proper way to protect the long-term safety of the community.
I call on the Government of Canada to reverse its decision regarding the Atomic Energy Control Board office. I call on the Government of Canada to put in place new effective adjustment programs to assist workers who have lost their jobs and to take new initiatives to diversify the economy of Elliot Lake and the north shore communities.

March 11, 1992

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since 1987, the federal government through a regional program called FEDNOR has created a total of 474 projects worth $127 million, with $36.2 million from the federal government, and created over 3,000 jobs.
In my hand today I have hundreds of letters endorsed by the Chamber of Commerce, town councils, residents and business people urging that this program continue.
I have yet to hear from the other side, from the member for Sudbury who has a regional office there, from the member for Thunder Bay who has an office there, or from the member for Sault Ste. Marie who has an office there, about whether or not they support FEDNOR.
It is a program that was brought together by northern Ontarians for northern Ontarians to develop the north. We need FEDNOR.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this year's commemoration of Shabbat Zachor, the sabbath of remembrance and prayer for the Jewish community of Syria, will be held on March 14 in synagogues across Canada.
On that day, not only Jews but all Canadians are reminded of the oppressive treatment of 4,300 Syrian Jews, including surveillance by Syrian secret police, economic restrictions and denial of basic human rights such as the right to vote, freedom of assembly, freedom from arbitrated tension and the right to emigrate, in contravention of the UN Declaration of Human Rights.
The plight of two brothers, Selim and Eli Swed, serving six and a half year sentences after unfair trials, is particularly grave. Recently members of this House and the Senate from all parties joined to form the Canadian Parliamentary Friendship Group for Syrian Jewry.
As vice-chair of this group, I join with my colleagues in commemorating Shabbat Zachor, and in strongly urging the Syrian government to release the Swed brothers and ensure that at last there is full respect for the fundamental human rights of all Syrian Jews, including the right to emigrate.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Ides of March are not yet upon us, but I, like the soothsayer, want to warn all Canadian senior citizens that Preston Manning and his retreads want to benefit from you when you die. That's right folks. Just call up some Reform Party office and you will be given the name of an insurance agent who will assist in a peaceful way, especially if you are aged and ill. They will transfer your life insurance policy directly to the Reform Party instead of your loved ones.
Preston then will likely send you a beautiful letter stating that when the time comes you will be dearly missed but heaven is waiting. Signed with anticipation, Preston.
P.S. Have you any older relatives we could contact? God bless.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is International Women's Week. We should be celebrating the advancement of women. Instead, this government is continuing its shameful record of contempt concerning Canadian women.
This week we have been debating a budget which tells working women they do not deserve retraining by cutting the Canadian Jobs Strategy by another $100 million; circumvents the Human Rights Tribunal and the Federal Court by reneging on a billion dollars of pay equity payments; reneges on the government's promise to promote equality rights by killing the Court Challenges Program; kills family allowances in favour of a targeted benefit which does nothing for families on social assistance, many of whom are headed by women; condemns more women and their children to homelessness by eliminating co-op housing. It has also reneged on its promise of child care.
March 11, 1992

This government signed the UN Convention on the elimination of discrimination against women. Canada should be implementing policies here at home which would serve as a model for the world. But no. What this government is saying to women is: "Wait a while longer".

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is reported that the CBC refuses to run a paid ad promoting Canadian unity. It says that it does not want to get political, it might offend someone.
This corporation, which does not want to get political, is quite happy giving publicity to Loretta Swit of MASH fame as she sits on an ice floe beside a seal.
Apparently it is not too political to give publicity to the affluent Hollywood star while giving short shift to the beleaguered Atlantic cod fishery.
Without a united Canada there will not be $1 billion in taxes to pay for the CBC. There will not be any need for a national network because there will not be a nation.
Without unity in Canada there will not be a need for the mother corporation. Perhaps the CBC should consider why it exists, who it exists for and spend a moment thinking about the "Canadian" in their name.
Without getting too political, I think the CBC should get its priorities straight.

subtopic

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister.
I have not always agreed with him in the past, and I still feel there are a number of major issues on which we disagree strongly. However, I do agree with the Prime Minister that we must use all the means at our disposal to achieve reconciliation and put together a set of proposals for this country that are acceptable to all Canadians. And that is why all members of the parlia-
Oral Questions
mentary committee voted for the Beaudoin-Dobbie report.
I would like to ask the Prime Minister whether the Minister of National Defence was speaking on behalf of the Canadian government when he attacked the Beaudoin-Dobbie report yesterday.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the transcript of last night's broadcast of Le Point, where Mr. Masse was a guest. He said the following: "Looking at this from an historical perspective, I entirely agree with the Prime Minister that the Beaudoin-Dobbie report goes further than any other in terms of being open to the needs of Quebec and taking into account the particular situation in Quebec".
Mr. Masse confirms what I said on Mr. Coumoyer's radio show last week. I said that although Beaudoin-Dobbie was the product of a parliamentary committee and thus not necessarily government policy, it nevertheless remains a document that is very important as part of Canada's constitutional development and in my opinion, its approach to the provinces, to aboriginal people, to institutional reform-and here I am thinking of the Senate-and to the distribution of powers is the most generous and the most open approach this country has seen in 125 years.
The report and the parliamentarians from all political parties in this House, whose efforts and spirit of co-operation were exemplary, deserve our respect.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I like the statement of the Prime Minister, but I would like to ask him this question.
After 18 members of his caucus, plus members from this side of the House, the NDP and Liberals, signed the report and the Prime Minister and the minister in charge of the Constitution said last week it was a good report, is it not the obligation of every member of the government to defend what the Prime Minister calls "the best constitutional proposition since 1867"?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a parliamentary report and it is not a question of government policy. We are examining it very carefully. As I have just indicated, I quite frankly am very impressed by the work of the committee.

Oral Questions
The Minister of National Defence indicated last night on television-
"I entirely agree with the Prime Minister. This report goes further than any other in terms of being open to the needs of Quebec".

This is a substantial statement of agreement and an endorsement of the position of all of the people who worked so hard to put together the report. At an appropriate time, the House will be-
Come on.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext: The Bloc Quebecois does not agree. The poor Bloc Quebecois is trying to destroy a great country and it is going to be surprised when Quebecers are confronted with the real question and they say "We want to remain Canadians.".

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speakerposition: Leader of the Official Opposition
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would like to know from the Prime Minister whether it would not be better for all Canadians if the members of his cabinet did what they had to do to be applauded by members of the Conservative Party, instead of being applauded by members of the Parti Quebecois, as was Mr. Masse.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I just said twice that the Minister of National Defence, on Le Point last night, fully endorsed the position I had defended on Jean Cournoyer's program. Now if my friend is complaining that there may be differences of opinion from time to time within a political party, I am sorry, but I would point out the huge difference between his position and that of the hon. member for Saint-Henri-Westmount.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext: Yes, it happens in the best of families. It is not perfect. You do not have total solidarity yet. So those are things that happen. The Minister of National Defence said last night that he fully supported the Prime Minister's position, and I congratulate him on his good judgment.

Mr. Speaker, in 1988 the Prime Minister said that the dispute settlement mechanism in the free trade agreement was: "a genuine shield against new U.S. protectionism.". Yet in the case of softwood lumber and of Honda automobiles that shield against new U.S. protection is obviously not there.
When will this government recognize that the free trade agreement is not providing the secure access to the American market which was its original justification? What is this government going to do to ensure that such protectionist abuse is eliminated in trade between Canada and the United States?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Ihade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is clear that under the free trade agreement, and I am sure my hon. friend would not have it any other way, each country has its own trade protective laws, laws to protect its own interests. We have applied ours in certain cases, the Americans applied theirs in other cases.
As I have said on many occasions, no other country in the world has a dispute settlement mechanism. We have it to ensure that the trade laws are applied in a fair, open and equitable way as far as both sides are concerned. That is what we have in the free trade agreement. That is a very important step forward with the free trade agreement, as we have seen most particularly with the pork decision not too long ago where Canadians interests were protected when they were under attack from protectionist forces in the United States.

Mr. Speaker, the free trade agreement merely provides for the evaluation of the fair application of U.S. trade law. When the government signed the memorandum of understanding in 1986 on softwood lumber, it did so largely because there was no agreement between Canada and the United States on the question of what is a subsidy. There is still no such agreement today.
Without a clear definition of subsidies, how can there be an effective process for dispute settlement?
March 11, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Tirade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, one of the key things that we did not have in 1986 was a free trade agreement with a dispute settlement mechanism. Now we have that important balance, important factor in the free trade agreement that allows for these disputes to be settled in a fair and equitable fashion.
My hon. friend talks about a definition of subsidy. We provided in the agreement, because we could not get an agreement at that time as to what would constitute the subsidy, five years within which we would establish that.
Since that time we have been discussing this under the auspices of the GATT and the Uruguay round negotiations. As my hon. friend knows from reading the Dunkel proposals of December 20, we have made a very important step forward as to what constitutes a subsidy. There is still more work to be done, but it is a major step forward in establishing the definition of subsidy.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. As the House knows, we are celebrating International Women's Week this week. Unfortunately the government's recent budget, with the total elimination of a national child care program and its refusal to honour the government's pay equity to the women in its employ, gives women little reason to celebrate.
The government has fought its female employees every step of the way, refusing to pay the $1 billion in pay equity that is owing to the women working for this government.
My question to the Prime Minister is this. Why is the government willing to give a $1 billion tax break so that corporate executives can have lunch with each other but it refuses to give the $1 billion to those women who have earned it?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think there would be general agreement in the House that the concept of equality for all Canadians, and particularly the one raised by my hon. friend, the
Oral Questions
advancement of the cause of equality for women, is a most important and very noble undertaking and the government and parliamentarians are committed to it.
I think in fairness my hon. friend should acknowledge that since this government came to office there has been an increase of over 100 per cent in the appointment of women to agencies, boards and commissions in decisionmaking positions.
When we became the government there were three women who were deputy ministers, there are now 21 at that level. There were two women who were ambassadors, there are now 16 or 17 heads of mission. We have added women to the Supreme Court and at the next cabinet meeting tomorrow-when we formed a government there were 37 women appointed to the federal bench across Canada-this government will be naming the one hundredth woman to fill a senior judicial position in Canada.
These are all very important advancements of women in our society into the decision-making process, making the decisions and exercising power where it really counts. That did not exist in the past. We have made very major steps forward but we have a long way to go.
I hope my hon. friend will bear these realities in mind and place them in context when she is asking her questions and commenting on the status of women in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the context is that business executives get a $1 billion tax break and women with lower incomes who work for this government do not get the pay equity that they deserve, that the courts have said that they deserve and that this government owes to these women. Those are the facts and noble intentions do not put bread on the table.
Because it also affects these lower income groups in our society, not only do women suffer from not having pay equity within the government and outside the government, but the government's tax changes that are announced in this budget also mean that lower income families are paying more taxes. The de-indexation of tax credits, which continues, means that more families are paying higher taxes in the lower income bracket, approximately $200 more in taxes.

March 11, 1992
Oral Questions
I ask the Prime Minister a simple question: With this de-indexation of tax credits, why has the government continued a hidden tax on the poor and working Canadian families?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that conclusion is absolutely false. There are two parts to the question. The first part deals with pay equity.
I remind the hon. member that we have made adjustments to pay equity on a retroactive basis going back to, I believe, April 1, 1985 of in excess of $400 million. I do not believe that there is any other administration or government in Canada that has undertaken that.
In addition to that, we provide for an additional $81 million for future pay equity provisions. Again, there is no other administration in Canada that is as generous as that.
With regard to the second part of the question, the hon. member should take a look again at the child benefit program. This is clearly designed, together with the earned income supplement and the very generous offerings as a result of the consolidation of the family allowance, the child credit and the refundable tax credit, so that working poor families with children will certainly be a lot better off.
Furthermore, unlike the family allowance which is now taxed away, the payments of up to $144 per month will be provided to 3.1 million families without being taxable. That clearly indicates this is a generous program. It is focused and it is simple.

Mr. Speaker, the truth remains that in this budget on which we will be voting today and on which this party will be voting against, not only is social housing cut back, not only is co-operative housing cut out, not only is pay equity not in it, the avenues that people have had to even challenge the government and to challenge those authorities is cut back.

Two years ago, the federal government said that it would continue to fund the Court Challenges Program, which helps the most disadvantaged.
The government explained that it wanted to reaffirm its commitment to promoting human rights.
I would like to ask the Prime Minister a question. This program was just cancelled in the budget. Does this mean that the government is no longer interested in promoting human rights in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it does not surprise me at all to learn that the New Democratic Party will be voting against tax cuts for 14.6 million Canadians.
It does not surprise me at all that the NDP will be voting against reducing deficits and reducing the size and scope of government. That does not surprise me at all.
The hon. member suggests that there are some programs that are being cut. Yes, indeed there are some programs that are being cut.
These are very difficult and tough decisions to make, but the fact of the matter is that Canadians do not want to see the deficit rise and they do not want to see their taxes rise. So the tough choices mean that you have to cut some programs. You cannot cut spending without cutting programs.

Mr. Speaker, the Honda syndrome will drive out not just automotive but all other manufacturing in Canada that is producing for the U.S. market.
In light of this, has the trade minister obtained the consent of the United States to binding arbitration of the Honda dispute? If not, why not?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the concern that my hon. friend is expressing about the Honda issue is precisely the same concern that we have as a government and that we are acting on in the activities that we have undertaken in dealing with this matter with the United States administration.
We have initiated discussions with them under chapter 18 of the free trade agreement. Those consultations continue in two senses. Once those consultations are
March 11, 1992

completed we will decide whether or not it is appropriate to have some other form of consultation.

Mr. Speaker, the minister's idea of talking tough with the Americans is to beg on his knees and prostrate himself in Washington.
He still cannot get the Americans, as he admitted today, to agree to binding arbitration on the Honda dispute under chapter 18. Will the minister at least admit that his much lauded dispute settlement mechanism under chapter 18 of the free trade agreement just is not worth the paper it is written on?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the excessive rhetoric is totally inappropriate. TTiere are three ways that we can have consultations with the United States administration.
One is through the normal operations of the U.S.-Canada Trade Commission which meets at least two times a year. The second is chapter 18-
Which you are using, you said.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
If my hon. friend would be patient for a minute, I will give him the full answer.
Chapter 18 is the second basis on which we can have consultations which are not binding. Chapter 19 is a binding dispute mechanism that is the final stage.
My hon. friend should understand that prior to the free trade agreement we had none of those three means by which we could have this type of consultation. We now have a free trade agreement with these ways with which we can discuss these issues which are bound to come up in a trade relationship as broad and as deep as we have with the United States. That is the value of the free trade agreement in dealing with this type of dispute.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, during Monday's Question Period, the Prime Minister indicated that he and the government are considering a number of options with respect to the foreign overfishing issue.
Oral Questions
At that time he invited me to make some suggestions to him. I have one for him. Take immediate steps to extend functional jurisdiction over the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. There is my suggestion. Is is ready to act on it?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is indeed a unique suggestion. The hon. gentleman is going to take over functional jurisdiction of international fishing activities outside the 200 miles when there is no other nation in the world that has said it would agree to Canada or any other country taking that course of action.
That is an invitation to conflict. That is not reasonable or sensible. That is simply trying to make oneself appealing to those who would like to see direct action when this is a complicated world and direct actions are not always the kind of actions that one can take.
For example, we were down in New York pursuing this matter at the UNCED conference where we have a chance of getting the rest of the world to agree with us. The rest of the world is not going to agree with us if we simply go out making heroic gestures that the rest of the world is bound not to observe, including all of the powerful industrial countries of the world, all of whom believe in freedom of the high seas.

Yes, Mr. Speaker, he has been down in New York and last year he was over in Strasbourg. Last week, some of his colleagues were in Strasbourg. They have come back this week to tell him that our lobbying effort over there is absolutely non-existent or to the degree it exists, it is an absolute joke.
The best proof of that is the cockamamie stuff that the British MPs are saying these days about seals and sealing. The government has no lobby campaign. It is a joke.
I ask him, would he now return to his position of some weeks ago when his Prime Minister was not listening, when he was in Newfoundland and he said he was running out of patience. Has he run out of patience? Is he now prepared to do what I suggested just now and what he himself suggested in little groups back in Newfoundland?

March 11, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member becomes more imaginative as he goes on.
We can adopt either an attitude of posturing or beating our chests. The hon. gentlemen reminds me of King Kong except he is not quite the same size. I am more in the Kong size myself. I see there is general agreement with my reply so I am sitting down.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there will be those who make claim that what you get now is Kong II.
I have a question for the Minister of Finance. On January 27, a mere four weeks before the budget killed the co-op housing program, the Minister of Finance wrote to the president of the Co-operative Housing Federation of Canada, indicating the program would continue for 1992-93 with a new funding commitment of $6.1 million.
On February 19, less than a week before the program's public execution, the Minister of Public Works wrote a similar letter to the president of the Conseil de la cooperation du Quebec.
Did the Minister of Finance truly not know the program would be eliminated when he wrote his January 27 letter? Had no one bothered to tell the minister responsible less than a week before the budget? If the two ministers did know, how can the wholly incorrect assurances contained in their letters possibly be explained?

speakeroldname: Mr. Dave Worthy (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the cuts that were necessary in the budget reduced the social housing spending to 3 per cent. This is unfortunate but it was a move that had to be taken. People in this country understand that.
Obviously there are alternatives. We could take the money from the seniors and apply it. We could take money from other places. This government has decided not to do that. We feel this is the proper move for the proper time.

Mr. Speaker, that is a fascinating, if somewhat inadequate, answer but it completely ignores the question unfortunately, as did the minister to whom it was directed.
Might I ask the Minister of Finance whether he really believes that the depths of a protracted recession is the right time to cut funding for new social housing by half over the next two years? Does he not think this is both socially cruel and economically lunatic, especially when, in another part of the budget, strenuous efforts are undertaken to spur new housing construction? Or does he believe that the poor and those of moderate income characteristically have wads of cash stashed away in RRSPs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows, I am sure, that the Government of Canada spends in excess of $2 billion annually on social housing and will continue to do that.
With respect to social housing, I think the hon. member would also know that 50 per cent of those living in co-op housing would not be eligible and, therefore, do not really qualify for social housing under the criteria established.
It is important to ensure that we channel scarce resources to those in most need. That is exactly what this budget does. That is exactly what is happening under the continuing support for the social housing which will increase this year by $70 million and $45 million every year thereafter. That creates an ongoing obligation for 35 years.
Mr. Speaker, no wonder this minister killed the co-op housing program. He does not even understand what it is all about and what need it fills for Canadians. One week ago-

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: Perhaps, the hon. member would want to put his question appropriately.

Mr. Speaker, this government made a commitment and a guarantee to provide $6 million to the co-op housing program in 1992.
There are 164,000 Canadians on a waiting list for co-op housing. By eliminating the funding for co-op housing this government is abdicating its responsibility to those Canadians and, in fact, is causing 4,500 jobs to be lost in the construction industry.

My question is a very simple one. Will the minister honour the commitment to the co-op housing program for 1992. Can they keep one promise to this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the government will continue to support the 14,800 housing units that are in existence as a result of the co-op housing program and we will continue to support social housing to the tune of $2 billion a year.
When it comes to creating activity in the housing industry, the reduction in the CMHC down payment to 5 per cent and the RRSP initiative are clear initiatives that will support and stimulate housing in all parts of the country. I think the hon. member would welcome that.

Mr. Speaker, the $6 million promised for 1992 was for the additional 1,800 badly needed units in this country.
The minister surely knows that the Co-op Housing Program is cost efficient and that the program is well targeted to those people who cannot own a home.
In Montreal, Toronto and other centres the Co-op Housing Program provides support for single parents, the disabled, seniors, and groups that cannot find affordable housing.
Will the minister reinstate the funds for 1992? Will he reinstate this program that helps Canadians with affordable housing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member may want to reconsider his comment when he suggests that the housing provided for under the Co-op Housing Program is well targeted.
Truly 50 per cent of those who occupy housing provided under this program would not qualify under the social housing criteria. I ask him then: How is it that it is well targeted when 50 per cent of those who occupy these units are not in effect qualified under the provisions of social housing?

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport in light of his announcement this morning concerning Pearson airport.
Oral Questions
The timing of the minister's announcement of the privatization of terminals 1 and 2 has to be questionable at best, given the recession, the problems in the Canadian airline industry, the far from certain commercial success of terminal 3, and the ongoing environmental review of runway expansion.
Why is the minister rejecting the advice of the private sector, provincial and municipal officials, as well perhaps as some of his own officials, in going ahead with privatization now?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is rather amusing that members on the other side have been saying for weeks and months that this government should spend money to create jobs. Now we come forward with a project that is going to create 3,200 jobs for five years in well paying industries in the Toronto area and this member is complaining again. I do not know what he is doing.

Mr. Speaker, we will be interested to hear his explanation of those numbers in another forum, but I would like to know now not only about his timing but also about the process that he has introduced today.
The minister proposes to turn over Canada's most profitable airport to private developers and he is giving interested parties only 90 days to submit comprehensive proposals which contemplate two different environmental review results.
How can the minister seriously expect Canadians to believe that within 90 days this process is open to all possibly interested parties and that this action will produce the best possible result for travellers and for Canadian taxpayers who have already put a lot of money into terminal 2?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, obviously a development of this kind is not to provide for the needs of today but the needs of tomorrow.
In 1988 these were the same people who were complaining that the government had not exercised enough foresight in not making more space available to accommodate the traffic that was increasing. It created congestion that no one wants to go through again.
We have studies that indicate that the traffic in the airline industry has been increasing by 4.5 per cent a year for the past 10 years. Our present forecast of 3 per cent a year for the next years indicates that we will lack capacity

March 11, 1992
Oral Questions
in 1997-98 without the new runways. This is why we are proceeding at this time.
We indicated four years ago that we were going to transfer all airports in areas where people want it to local airport authorities. We are following the course that we implemented four years ago and it is working well.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to ask the Prime Minister a question.
What the Minister of National Defence said yesterday is that the Beaudoin-Dobbie report is unacceptable for Quebec.
He is not the only one to think so because right now members of the Quebec Liberal Party and the Parti Quebecois are voting unanimously on a motion which concludes that "the National Assembly disapproves of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee report."
When will the Prime Minister stop pretending with the Leader of the Opposition, the leader of the Liberal Party of Canada, that something good can come of a report that English Canada considers too generous and Quebec considers not enough?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Perhaps it is the hon. member who should stop pretending. The Beaudoin-Dobbie report reflects the five conditions of the Meech Lake Accord, I repeat, the five conditions or proposals that he supported barely a year and a half ago.
Besides, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee report contains a series of provisions, of new measures for the provinces, native people and institutional reform in Canada, including, for example, Senate reform. Mr. Dubuc, as well as Mr. Auger of the Journal de Montreal, think that these provisions are a very serious step forward for Quebec and the other provinces.
No one claimed that it was a final position. The House itself will be presented with the document and the
House will decide in due course. But for someone, especially someone who already vigorously supported the five conditions of Meech, to now denounce a document as insufficient when it already contains much more than Meech is unprecedented hypocrisy in the House of Commons.

Mr. Speaker, whatever our allegiances, we will all agree that an essential element in this debate is truth and that if we had more respect for the truth, we would go further.
The one who most vigorously approved the Meech Lake Accord is one of its signers, Robert Bourassa. Today he says no to the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee report because it does not reflect the five conditions of Meech Lake.
When will we stop wasting time and money and frightening people in Quebec as in English Canada and when will this offer that is supposed to come finally be tabled?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I think that no one in Canada or in Quebec would believe that we have anything to learn from that member when it comes to truth and loyalty.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
He has become a legend and we will talk about it for decades to come. He will always be mentioned as a model of truthfulness and loyalty for generations to come, I am sure.
As for the document and the position that the Parliament of Canada is to take, in due time, of course, Quebecers will be called upon to decide their future. In 1980, they were presented with a question. Perhaps there will be another one in 1992, to be decided on with proper reflection, in an unbiased, objective, serene way. Quebecers will be presented with a basic question. And if you allow me to speak now just as a Quebecer, a guy from the North Shore, if the question is "Do you prefer a renewed Canada or an independent Quebec?", Quebecers will choose a renewed Canada ten times out of ten.

Hear, hear.
March 11, 1992

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister answering on behalf of the Minister of National Revenue.
Yesterday I gave the Minister of National Revenue a copy of the Reform Party mailout which explains how the political tax credit can be used to pay for insurance policies that benefit the Reform Party. At that time I asked the minister for an inquiry. I believe that the document, while it pretends to be a report of one person's generous gift to the Reform Party, is really a slick, sophisticated and sleazy step-by-step guide on how to abuse the tax system.
Will the government order an inquiry?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of National Revenue is in Newfoundland on government business today.
Upon the member presenting this to the minister, he immediately asked his deputy minister for taxation matters to review it. According to the evidence that has been presented so far, they find that this scheme the Reform Party has dreamed up does not qualify as a political tax credit.
It is perfectly legitimate for charities. It is perfectly legitimate for universities, hospitals, churches, for example, to do this type of thing, but for a political party it is not.
It is rather interesting that the Reform Party which advocates the abolition of political tax credits is using a method to raise funds that does not appear to be acceptable to Revenue Canada officials.

I have a supplementary question, Mr. Speaker.
Just so that the minister is perfectly clear because many Canadians will want to know the answer, it is perfectly legal for individuals to give through their wills or through their insurance policies to universities, to political parties, to charities. It is the abuse of the political tax credit that is in question. Is that correct?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
That is correct, Mr. Speaker.
Oral Questions
As a matter of fact the way the scheme works, as I understand it, is that they are encouraging their members to take out life insurance policies naming the Reform Party as the beneficiary and claiming a tax credit on the premiums paid on that polity.
To our way of thinking it is highly unethical and on first blush, on investigation, we find it totally illegal within the tax system of Canada.

speakerposition: subtopic
subtopic: ESTIMATES FOR THE HOUSE OF COMMONS
ESTIMATES FOR THE HOUSE OF COMMONS
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the hon. member for Lachine- Lac-Saint-Louis, as the representative of the Board of Internal Economy of the House of Commons. During the past week the media have been discussing the Estimates for the House of Commons for 1992-93, as they apply to members of this House. Could the representative of the Board of Internal Economy confirm when I will be able to receive a copy of this document, which is being held back by Parliament?

speakerposition: Progressive Conservative Party Caucus Chair
subtopic: ESTIMATES FOR THE HOUSE OF COMMONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, near the end of the last fiscal year the House management committee called the Speaker and his administrators as witnesses in its review and approval of the estimates for the House of Commons. Copies of the estimates were made available to members of Parliament upon request.
But a copy of this year's report entitled How the Budget is Spent-1992-93 has inadvertently or deliberately been released to the media prior to its being presented for review by the House management committee.
The matter of the unauthorized release of these estimates has been placed on the agenda of the Board of Internal Economy at its next meeting later this afternoon.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the minister responsible for children, my question is for the Prime Minister.

March 11, 1992
Oral Questions
The Caledon Institute of Social Policy has revealed that since 1986 this government has snatched $3.5 billion from Canadian children by not fully indexing child benefits.
Meanwhile, last February 11 the Minister of Finance announced a new loophole for wealthy Canadians to avoid paying tax on their private trusts for another generation.
When will this government end its policies of depriving Canadian children to finance new loopholes for the richest Canadians?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would like to repeat that the new approach taken to our social programs in the latest budget stresses this government's commitment to setting a priority on families and children. We can say that starting with this budget and this recommendation, families will have an additional $2 billion to spend in the next five years, which means $500 million for the current year.

Mr. Speaker, the new Tory ritual must be sacrificing children to the corporate gods.
The Budget Papers show that two-wage earner families with two children having a combined income of $30,000 will gratefully receive an extra $3.67 a month next year in child benefits. But, with inflation of just 3 per cent, this increase will vanish within the very next year.
I ask the minister if he will immediately move to index child benefits fully so that members on this side of the House will have one less thing to fix next year.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the measure we are proposing reflects the needs of Canadian children and was identified with the beneficiaries in the course of the usual consultations.
I maintain that the best way to protect the quality of our social programs is to keep inflation rates low and have a thriving economy, and that is what we are working on.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister will know that his government's 12-page child benefit white paper dealing with close to $5 million of expenditure is the shortest white paper in parliamentary history. He also knows that this minister will be meeting behind closed doors with the provinces and that not one of the many dozen anti-poverty or children's rights groups has been contacted.
In the absence of the Minister of Health and Welfare, could the Prime Minister indicate how Canadians will be involved? Is this yet another public relations gimmick or is the government for once going to speak to Canadians seriously about the future of their children?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Vezina (Minister of State (Employment and Immigration) and Minister of State (Seniors)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we are not in the House for a public relations exercise. We are working very hard to improve the quality of life of Canadians, their families and their children.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport and it is regarding proposed amendments to the Motor Vehicle Safety Act which currently provides two standards for safety in Canada: one for U.S. vehicles and a stiffer one for Canadian vehicles.
Will the new amendments remove section 902 which allows for this double standard and give the Canadian industry a level playing field?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as my hon. friend knows, we will shortly be bringing forward some amendments to the Motor Vehicle Safety Act. The intention of this act, after it is adopted, is to consult the people on the new regulations. I am sure that through this consultation process we will be able to address the well intentioned concerns of the member.
March 11, 1992

If there is not immediate agreement to allow us to have a speaker, namely the hon. member for Rosemont, we are not interested in simply giving an opportunity to others without being able to present a perspective from Quebec.
[English)

Mr. Speaker, I take the intervention of the hon. member quite seriously. I wish to indicate to him that the motion has been put with the best of intentions so that all members of this House will have an opportunity to debate a very important subject matter which affects certain regions more so than others. But to suggest that there ought to be preconditions before a

consent motion would be approved, I do not know if that is in the best interest of the House.
I wish to say, through you, Mr. Speaker, to the hon. member that we would be more than willing to try to co-operate with all members of this House to give everyone an opportunity to speak. If need be, perhaps certain provisions of the Standing Orders could be looked at in order to give greater opportunity to members who might want to speak for a shorter period of time rather than the 10 minutes which has been indicated in the consent motion.
I would hope that my hon. colleague will want to look at the motion, the spirit in which it has been given by the parties and he as a representative of a particular group, that we would have no difficulty whatsoever in trying to accommodate all members of this House.

subsubtopic: STUDENT LOANS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to table 90 petitions representing over 2,000 students at the University of British Columbia which is located, as you know, in my riding of Vancouver Quadra, a good many of them living, I am sure, in your own riding, Mr. Speaker.
It was bad enough when students were hit with the GST on their textbooks and the 3 per cent surcharge on student loans. The government has made matters worse with its plans to increase the burden of the cancelled 3 per cent surcharge by eliminating the interest-free repayment period.
On behalf of all of these students, I urge the government to reconsider its position.
speakername: Right Hon. John N. Timer@Vancouver Quadra

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subsubtopic: ARTICLE XI OF GATT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 have the honour and the privilege to table petitions signed by hundreds of farmers from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell who, of course, ask the Canadian government to pursue the strengthening and preservation of article XI of the GATT The petitioners certainly do not want the government from across to let this article be abolished in favour of tariffs.
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased, on behalf of all my colleagues, to support this petition from constituents of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell.

subsubtopic: DOMESTIC WORKERS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the privilege of submitting to the House 61 signatures of residents of Manitoba who petition and request that Parliament immediately ask the government to reinstate the foreign domestic program that was introduced back in 1981.
As you will well recognize, Mr. Speaker, the change in the regulations affecting domestic workers is both discriminatory and unfair and will seriously affect the child care system of this country. These 61 petitioners ask this
Routine Proceedings
Parliament to make their voice strongly heard to change that very unfair regulation.

subsubtopic: BILL C-230
speechtext:
While I am on my feet, I have 951 signatures, primarily from residents of Manitoba, but also from other parts of Canada where the petitioners humbly pray Parliament to give priority support to Bill C-230, an act to amend the Criminal Code of Canada, which provides for the appointment of an independent counsel to report to the Minister of Justice in cases where the minister receives an application for mercy.
If I might just say, we are all very aware of the daily newscasts of the proceedings in the David Milgaard case, the Nepoose case and certainly the Marshall case previously in Nova Scotia. It is quite clear that we need to reform the system whereby individuals who have been wrongly treated or in which their sentences and trials have not been to the proper standards of judicial rightness can make an appeal and not put the Minister of Justice in a position of having to deal with that, but have an independent counsel.
I humbly submit on behalf of these petitioners that request.

subsubtopic: RAILWAY LEVEL CROSSINGS
speechtext:
Pursuant to Standing Order 36, it is my honour and privilege to table a petition from the people of Stewiacke, Nova Scotia, where they have experienced a history of level crossing accidents in their community.
This petition urges increased safety standards at level crossings and also makes specific recommendations to the Railway Safety Act.

subsubtopic: UKRAINE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure of presenting a petition which, when it was circulated, had to do with the desire on the part of the petitioners that the Canadian government immediately recognize Ukraine following the referendum on December 1, 1991.
Of course that has been done, but I am sure the people who signed this petition would want to send a new message to the government, having to do with the need for continuing Canadian support for the new nation of Ukraine and the newly formed government there.

March 11, 1992
Routine Proceedings FAMILY VIOLENCE

subsubtopic: UKRAINE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I also have a petition which is signed by many residents of my riding and which arose out of the murder of a young woman there by the name of Marilyn Jensen.
These petitioners are concerned that whereas bail review provisions in the Criminal Code of Canada currently set out grounds for the release of accused offenders unless it can be proved that individual is a danger to society at large or it is likely that the accused person will not reappear in court; and whereas the problem of conjugal and family violence is a matter of grave concern for all Canadians, these petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to amend the Criminal Code of Canada to permit the courts to prevent the release of individuals where it is shown that there is a substantial likelihood of further conjugal or family violence being perpetrated.

subsubtopic: GASOLINE PRICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure of introducing in the House a petition signed by constituents of Ottawa, Gloucester, Nepean, Kanata and also from the constituents of Manotick, Cornwall, Carlsbad Springs and so on.
These constituents are upset because they are paying high prices for gasoline when compared with those in the rest of the province.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Caucus Chair
subsubtopic: JUSTICE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure of submitting for the attention of the government and the House of Commons the signatures of hundreds of petitioners who are constituents of York West.
These petitioners are urging the government to revise and amend the Narcotics Control Act so that all assets and cash seized as a result of drug convictions do not go back, as they do now, to general revenues in Ottawa but instead become shared with local police forces and local organizations. They are on the leading edge of combating drugs on our behalf and on behalf of families who unfortunately have fallen victim to the drug malaise, particularly our young.

subsubtopic: FOOD IRRADIATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a number of petitions from residents of western Ontario.
The petitioners call on the House of Commons and Parliament of Canada assembled, requesting that food irradiation not become part of the food processing business in this country until we have unbiased, independent agencies and scientists do complete studies on the safety of consuming such food. They ask that the effects of long-term consumption and environmental dangers involved be studied as well.

subsubtopic: LOW-LEVEL FLIGHTS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have 94 signatures on a petition from people who are concerned with the continuing and increasing low-level flights over Labrador.
The petitioners ask us to join with the Assembly of First Nations, the Innu of Labrador and other aboriginal peoples of northern Canada in opposing the use of their lands for NATO-NORAD attack training.
They also demand that the government end all NO-RAD-NATO low-level flight training in Canada and redirect the funding of it to aboriginal uses and to protecting the environment of Canada.

subsubtopic: REFUGEES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I also have 164 signatures on petitions from people in quite a number of municipalities in Ontario, British Columbia and other parts of Canada.
The petitioners are concerned for the situation of the spouses and children of people who have been accepted in Canada as refugee claimants. They ask that the minister issue minister's permits to bring the spouses and dependant children of refugee candidates here when these people have been permitted to apply for landing rather than delaying perhaps several years until the landing has been effected. They ask that these families be allowed to be reunited now in Canada.

subsubtopic: JUSTICE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the honour of presenting three petitions from people in the constituency of Durham who request that the Parliament of Canada recognize that crimes of violence against the person are serious and abhorrent to society, and they ask the government to amend the Criminal Code, the

Bail Reform Act of 1972 and the Parole Act to reflect these societal attitudes.

subsubtopic: JUSTICE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker,
I have here over 500 petitions on which there are well over 20,000 signatures. This is to add to the over 250,000 signatures that I have already presented to the Clerk of the House and the thousands that have been presented by other members in the House of Commons.
These petitioners feel that there are serious deficiencies in the criminal justice system in Canada. They ask that Parliament recognize that crimes of violence against the person are serious and abhorrent to society and they ask the government to amend the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act of 1972 and further amend the Parole Act.

subsubtopic: HOUSING
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition signed by numerous Canadians, including many who are resident in my own housing co-op of Sundance in Edmonton and many residents of a neighbouring co-op, the Art Space Co-op.
This petition was circulated before the budget and it calls on the House to recognize housing as a shared provincial-federal responsibility and to support the federal non-profit co-operative housing program and to maintain the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation.
I do hope the government takes the words of this petition to heart.

subsubtopic: RURAL POST OFFICES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this government continues to systematically ravage rural Canada. One of the ways of doing that is with respect to rural post offices. The citizens of the community of Drake in Saskatchewan are very concerned about the future of the post office there. It is a very poorly kept secret that their post office is going to close imminently.
The petitioners call on this government to ensure that the Drake post office remains open and that in fact all rural post offices remain open. They want a place for their children to live and grow up in the future instead of ghost towns.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at a time when Canadians across this country are yearning for a new spirit of co-operation and unity within Canada, this Conservative budget unfortunately divides and discriminates. It discriminates against the most vulnerable people in our society.
I would like to say that the impact of this budget on the people in my riding of Vancouver East and other ridings like it where there are many people unemployed and on low incomes is particularly devastating.
There is no job creation for the millions of unemployed Canadians and job development funds are cut by another $100 million in this budget.
There is no help for farmers, fishermen and forestry workers whose work is the backbone of this country.
The recession, we know and it is predicted, will continue with less research or retraining programs to help people who are the victims of restructuring in industries.
Last week I attended Vancouver Tech High School in my riding. The students asked me particularly to raise the matter that they are very concerned that student loans have been cut and they will not be able to continue on into post-secondary education.
Women have been slapped down once again and betrayed as pay equity is denied them, pay equity which is owing to women public servants who have been underpaid over the years. This was, of course, required by the courts and yet the government is refusing to pay this debt to women.
Funds for litigation of equality cases are terminated as well.
March 11, 1992

The federal co-operative housing program also is being terminated. This is one of the most important and successful means of developing decent affordable housing for low income people, but also for a mixed income range of people in healthy communities.
As a British Columbian I want to particularly mention to the government that the termination of co-op housing and social housing programs have been strongly condemned by Premier Mike Harcourt of British Columbia and by the mayor and city council of Vancouver.
We know that this program and also native housing programs are particularly important and essential to homeless people and to develop affordable housing for families, particularly in communities like Vancouver East where we have had a lot of good co-op housing developments.
The Conservative budget also pits families with middle incomes, the middle class if you like, against low income people.
The budget does away with family allowances, which have been a right to families in former years and replaces this with the child tax credit, which is very limited and unfair. This credit is targeted presumably to low income people, but we learn that it is only for working people, not for people on welfare.
The de-indexing of the child tax credit we learn also means that over the period of the next few years the value of the tax credit will decrease, and this means in effect that families will get less than they receive now. So any way you look at it this is an unsound public policy.
The credit is supposed to be an incentive for parents to move off welfare and into the work place, but where are the jobs for these people who are unemployed? Where is the training for people who have been locked into welfare, to get into the work force? And how can single mothers hope to work when the government has done nothing about helping to develop child care programs across this country? They also have capped the CAP for three provinces.
So this child tax credit which presumably is to help solve the problems of child poverty are typical Tory hypocrisy. Are poor kids on welfare less deserving than the children of working parents, I ask you?
The Budget
The government gives lip service to the elimination of child poverty. However, I want to say that one in four of the children in Vancouver who are poor, and 60 per cent of these attend inner city schools in my riding, will not get help from this budget.
Federal cuts in transfer payments for health, education and social services also eliminate future opportunities for these families to break this poverty cycle.
If this government wants Canadians to feel better about Canada and about Conservatives, then this budget had better be scrapped right now.
As NDP spokesperson for multiculturalism and citizenship, I want to strongly protest the budget measures that are designed to stifle advocacy and advice, that terminate advisory groups to the government, that kills the Court Challenges Program, and that once again betrays Canadians of Japanese origin who were promised a race relations foundation as part of their redress settlement.
Ethnic communities were also promised a heritage language institute to partially compensate for the cuts that this government made to community language programs. They have also been betrayed since the implementation of the new Race Relations Institute which we passed in this house will also be indefinitely postponed.
I want to concentrate my remaining time on the question of the termination of the Court Challenges Program and the Race Relations Foundation. These two decisions show that this government has no real commitment to social justice and to human rights.
When times get tough the government chops the programs that are vital to implementing the goals of our charter. It makes a mockery of the present constitutional negotiations when the government can so readily ignore human rights and protections for minorities which should be defended under our Charter.
I have raised the question of our very serious concern about the termination of the Court Challenges Program on two occasions in this House. On February 27, the minister for multiculturalism replied to me: "There is now a solid base of jurisprudence and the remaining finer points are those of provincial jurisdiction." The

March 11, 1992
The Budget
federal government is not doing its job. It is going to presume to pass it along to the provinces.
This is not the opinion of the former justice of the Supreme Court, Bertha Wilson, an outstanding judge, who said the following in a recent letter to the Minister of Justice:
- it is totally illusory to confer rights on people who do not have the means to enforce them and I assumed that the expansion of the Court Challenges Program following the advent of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms was an effort to address this problem.
I saw for myself when I was a member of the Supreme Court how invaluable this program has been to minority groups and to the disadvantaged. It has clearly been well and efficiently administered and has resulted in an excellent input into many very significant "test" cases-the public has unquestionably received full value for its money on this particular program-may I respectfully add my voice to what I am sure is a chorus of disapproval of the cancellation of this very imaginative and worth-while program.
This is from Bertha Wilson, an outstanding former judge of the Supreme Court.
The Race Relations Foundation was a commitment by this government, as I said earlier, to the redress settlement for the Japanese-Canadian community. Art Miki, president of the National Association of Japanese Canadians says the following:
Racism is a major concern for many Canadians, especially those from minority groups who are often the victims. There is a grave need for the foundation to facilitate the development, sharing and application of knowledge and expertise in order to achieve the elimination of racism and racial discrimination in Canada. This delay will have serious consequences in our efforts to fight racism.
It is in these periods that racism becomes more prominent in our society.
He goes on again to appeal to the government to retain its promise and to implement the Race Relations Foundation.
In conclusion, I would like to say that this government's budget policies seem to be trying to out-reform the Reform Party, hoping perhaps to gain votes. A government which attacks the poorest people in society, which refuses to protect the rights of minorities and women, which reneges on its stated priority to fight racism and which continues to work only for the wealthy and privileged is not going to regain the respect and
support of Canadians. It will be defeated and soon, we hope.

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to take part in the budget debate today. I would like to start by congratulating my colleague, the Minister of Finance, on his firm and clear emphasis in this, his first budget, on reducing the deficit, strengthening Canada's economy and building toward increased prosperity for all Canadians.
This budget reflects the ongoing commitment of a fiscally responsible government to an increasingly competitive Canadian industry within a global economy and a spirit of equity in all sectors of our society.
A number of government initiatives are aimed at expenditure reduction and enhancing competitiveness and prosperity. As Minister of Tbansport, I am proud to play a role in this respect.
As you know, the Minister of Finance announced a 3 per cent reduction in non-wage operating budgets for 1992-93. Transport Canada and the agencies for which I am responsible will contribute about $14 million, with $9 million directly from Transport Canada, $3.2 million from VIA and $1.6 from Marine Atlantic.
I am glad to say that VIA and Marine Atlantic will continue to reduce their dependence on federal subsidies.

I might note that reduced revenues from sources such as the air ticket tax in 1992-93, over $100 million, will result in an additional cut in departmental spending beyond the 3 per cent over-all cut.
In order to deal with this revenue shortfall, a combination of measures will be required to reduce or defer costs. As the economy improves, additional revenue will reduce the department's over-all requirement for government funds and permit more capital investment.
To streamline government, some 46 new government agencies, boards, commissions, corporations and advisory bodies will be eliminated, consolidated, deferred or privatized.
March 11, 1992

In Transport Canada, the ministerial task force on international air policy, the Marine Advisory Board on Research and Development and CN West Indies have been terminated.
Transport Canada will generate savings to management improvements and enhance the government and industry co-operation at the Motor Vehicle Test Centre at Blainville, Quebec. The government will be examining the feasibility of privatizing the centre.
As part of the rationalization of government assets, the government also will be speeding up the pace of surplus property disposal including surplus lands held by Transport Canada at Pickering, Ontario.

Mr. Speaker, transportation has a very important role to play in Canada's economic recovery. In fact, transportation is what helped build this great country of ours.
Railroads extend from coast to coast. Ships maintain our links with Europe and the countries of the Pacific Rim. Airports move people and goods quickly and efficiently.
As Canadians, we must carefully review our investment in this vital infrastructure.
The Government of Canada is working closely with provincial and territorial governments on ways to meet this very basic challenge.
At the last First Ministers meeting, a number of governments emphasized the importance of having an infrastructure in keeping with our need to be competitive.
As far as our national road network is concerned, a federal-provincial-territorial process has already begun. Transport ministers will be meeting in the fall to discuss various options for financing the improvements needed to bring the network up to contemporary standards. In its 1992 budget, the federal government indicated that we are prepared to work with the provinces on exploring ways to improve our national road network in a way that is financially responsible.
The dialogue on renewing transportation infrastructure in general is already well under way with the provinces. I am confident that our discussions will be useful and help us identify appropriate methods of funding, given the present financial environment; in that way, we might have the monetary resources required for
The Budget
the highway infrastructure that is essential to our country's economic prosperity.
Mr. Speaker, our government is actively committed to establishing a fixed link between New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island, with private funding.
