Transport Canada also works very closely with the private sector to develop airport facilities while reducing government spending.
At Pearson International Airport, the development and funding of terminal 3 by the private sector are an example of successful co-operation between the private and public sectors.
This very morning, Mr. Speaker, we launched an official request for proposals process, asking the private sector to finance the upgrading of Terminals 1 and 2 and to manage them under a lease.
We are also looking into the possibility of increasing the capacity of Vancouver International Airport, as part of a transfer of this airport to a local airport authority. The transfer agreement includes provisions concerning airside and landside expansions through a private source of funding.
In the coming days, we will proceed with the transfer of Dorval and Mirabel airports in Montreal and the Vancouver, Calgary and Edmonton airports to local airport authorities. Other cities such as Moncton, Quebec, Windsor, Thunder Bay, Winnipeg and Kamloops are also being carefully considered for similar transfers.
As the Minister of Finance said, Canadians know that sound social and economic policies must be complementary.
In this regard, the budget provides several important measures to help disabled Canadians. These measures are part of a national strategy officially launched last September by the Prime Minister, the Right Hon. Brian Mulroney, which provides $158 million to integrate the disabled.
This is a field which interests me greatly. An advisory committee on accessible transportation, representing several organizations of the disabled, is working within my department to advise me specifically on this very important area. Last fall, I was pleased to announce to that committee that Transport Canada, through the government's national strategy, would provide $24.6

March 11, 1992
The Budget
million to the transport industry in order to improve accessibility for travellers.
Our involvement in this national strategy will encourage the industry to design and use material that will promote accessibility to transports. The commitment made by Transport Canada will complement the existing initiatives regarding accessibility and will give concrete results that handicapped people will benefit from.
Mr. Speaker, there is no doubt that this budget is a responsible one, both from a social and financial perspective. The direction that we have taken is clearly a road toward economic recovery. Canadians can expect an enhanced competitiveness as well as growing prosperity. In spite of what some might say, we are on the road to unity and, together, we will recognize the benefits of a united Canada through co-operation, as well as the sum of all its parts. Prosperity is clearly the result of a concerted effort, not of some irresponsible action to divide the country.
It is together that we will be able to meet all the challenges of the future, and I urge all Canadiens to be united.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened attentively to the minister's remarks and I share some of his sentiments toward the Minister of Finance's first budget. I have the highest respect for him.
However, I have concern about the minister's department, transportation, and the effect this budget will have on it.
I want to be very specific. For me the Department of Transport has always been a great anchor for the Canadian presence in every region of our country. The airports and marine ports, all of those instruments which come under the responsibility of this minister, have always been instruments that the national government was able to use to promote tourism and welcome people here from all over the world. Now we are in the process of privatizing these instruments.
I refer specifically to the example the minister used in his remarks, terminals 1 and 2. For the life of me, I cannot understand why we are privatizing terminals 1 and 2 when we just finished spending $140 million of
taxpayers' money on them. The market is depressed. I do not know how much money we are going to get for terminals 1 and 2. Terminal 3 right now, according to the owners, is a tremendous financial burden for them. It is not working out, there are law suits all over the place. But I do not want to get into the privatization aspect of this. We can debate it another day.
I need to ask the minister a very specific question. Does he not think that as we dismantle the Canadian presence in every part of this country that it is going to make it much more difficult to sell the idea of Canada as a whole, when all of those federal presence instruments are being ripped away from us or sold? Does he not think it is going to make his job as a federalist to sell Canada more difficult?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to congratulate the hon. member for his concern about the unity of this country and the job that we all share as members of this House and also as Canadians to assure that this country remains united. We have accomplished a lot over the last 125 years despite our diversity and our weaknesses in some respects and our strengths in other respects.
I think that Transport Canada, through its various institutions and facilities, has greatly contributed to the achievements that we have attained over the past 125 years.
I believe we are still very much involved in maintaining this very valuable relationship between all regions of Canada through the facilities of Transport Canada. However, at the same time, we have to face up to the reality that we have accumulated a very high national debt over the years and that we are living through a very difficult period where we are wrestling to reduce the enormous annual deficit. Because Canadians have indicated in many areas that they are not prepared to accept any more taxes, that they have reached their limit, we therefore have to find ways and methods of doing what we have to do with less financial resources.
Therefore, we have to be more inventive, more innovative. This is what we have been doing over the past few years. For instance, this idea of leasing the airports to local airport authorities is one way we can maintain our presence. Transport Canada is not going to abandon the airports, it will retain its responsibility for safety and security and will therefore maintain a very strong presence. But at the same time we will leave to the
March 11, 1992

commercial enterprises what they do best, which is operating the commercial aspect of the airport.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I too want to pay tribute to the Minister of Finance on his first budget, not only because it is a budget which he gave in eminently fine style and content but also because he is the first westerner to present a budget to this House in almost living memory, as far as I can trace it back. In recent memory he is the first westerner to present a budget. I am proud to be associated with him and to say that he has done westerners proud in presenting it.
As I reflect on budget night, I would draw members' attention to the reality of the experience. It is a bit of theatre, a bit of a show outside the Chamber. We have scrum upon scrum, where television personalities and interviewers are interviewing all the interest groups that come to Ottawa on the evening when the budget is presented.
It seems as though our narcissistic society reads the budget, almost exclusively, almost entirely in the context of their own immediate sphere of self-interest.
If fishermen are not specifically mentioned in the budget then there is nothing in it for fishermen, even though the benefits of previous budgets are still continuing on to this day. If there is not something in it for this day, then there is nothing in it for fishermen. If it is not quite to the expectations of the business community, if the tax cuts are not quite as big or quite as broad as they would like, then it is not a good budget and it has to be roundly condemned. If labour sees it as not having enough input in the responses, then it is not a good budget and it is rejected holus bolus.
It is a bit of a tragedy that we are treated on that night with an instantaneous appraisal of a very complex document and it is supposed to be accepted or rejected on the spur of the moment on the basis of a person's own self-interest.
I recall watching it that evening. They are walking down the corridor to meet another businessman whose name I think all members here would recognize if I mentioned it. He is in an industry that is under a great deal of competitive pressure and is a very heavily taxed
The Budget
industry. As I say, people would recognize his name if I mentioned it.
So I said to him: "What do you think of the budget tonight?" Immediately he said: "Well, it is doing nothing for me but it is good for Canada". You can imagine my pleasure, the tonic it was for me, to have one businessman who could have justifiably looked for some kind of relief in this budget for his particular industry, yet he said it did nothing for him but it was good for Canada. Surely we can use a lot more of that in our country.
So I say this is refreshing. It is refreshing because he saw that this budget contained a reaffirmation of the values that have made Canada the great country that it is today, some very important values. First of all, let me quote from a report. Since most members would not want me to quote from a government document, I presume, I will quote Deloitte & Touche. There is a reaffirmation of values and it has to do with minimum intrusiveness. Listen to what the commentary says:
Resisting the entreaties of the provinces and special interest groups for quick-fix spending to jolt the economy out of its lethargy, finance minister Donald Mazankowski has repeated the message of his predecessor, restrain costs, cut the deficit and some day soon a reduction in the government debt will be the result.
He goes on to say:
Sound policies for times of economic uncertainties is one way of briefly describing finance minister Mazankowski's maiden budget speech. After last year's tough-minded budget with its extension of expenditure control to five years, tax increases and wage freezes, this year's speech seems like a relatively cheery affair. In essence though, it hides a frugal government's spending program behind fiscal goodies which sound expansive but which will not over-stimulate the economy.
The key sentence is this.
Full marks to the minister for a politically astute budget with minimum intrusive effects on the economy.
All of us know that whenever a budget is brought down, you cannot avoid intrusiveness in the economy. The trick is to bring down a budget that minimizes that intrusiveness. That is something which I think the business community values and is very important.
The second value that is important is it is a budget to enhance competitiveness in our economy. Taxes are meant to increase revenue for the government to carry on its programs. That is the their purpose. I think that is a fairly accurate truism. But if the taxes become too high, they become a disincentive to business and the very purpose of those taxes is frustrated because the more taxes imposed on people, the more it creates a disincen-

March 11, 1992
The Budget
tive to function. Rather than increase the revenues it tends to decrease the revenues and makes businesses uncompetitive.
By reducing taxes, by improving the capital cost allowances to industry, by improving the benefits to industry if it carries on R and D and by reducing the surtax, the budget is increasing the competitiveness of the business community. Already we have heard the business community across Canada give approval to that. There is increased competitiveness and that is a value for Canadian society.
Third, there was an increase in consultation. It has been a pattern with our ministers of finance to carry on consultations across Canada with all interest groups that would be affected by a budget. Historically the Minister of Finance or his officials meet with one particular group. Whether it is a manufacturing sector, the agricultural sector, the labour sector or the social housing sector, they meet with them independently of each other and hear what their views are. This time they added a new process and put numbers of these together in a room. When one interest group was asking for one provision, it was balanced off with another interest group in the same room saying: "Wait a minute, guess what you will do to me if we introduce that provision".
There was not only an increase in the amount of consultation but an increase in the intensity of that consultation. It was a pre-budget consultation. It was a face-to-face consultation. It pitted one interest group against the other so that we would reduce it to what it ought to be. It was very important.
These are the values largely on the business side. Then there are those which are on the social side. We have heard it said many times that the purpose of a good economy is to spread the benefits to those who may have less advantage.
I would like to focus on the fact that this budget re-establishes and focuses on the integrity of the family unit. Already I have received mail from people who have said: "I am glad this Minister of Finance has recognized, for example, that previous budgets have been prejudiced against the traditional family unit".

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: How many? One, two?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I have received some. The public is slow in responding but it is responding. It is encouraging when people write and say: "You are recognizing the strong historic values and the place of the family in our society". This budget does that in addition to the fact that we cany on the child care programs.
Finally I want to mention that the next step is that provinces are now going to bring in their budgets. While there is slack which our Minister of Finance has introduced into the tax regime, such slack as reducing the surtax, I would urge or I would challenge provincial governments not to take up that slack and impose that extra tax by way of the provincial treasuries. I challenge my own province of British Columbia which is bringing down its budget in about two weeks' time to resist that temptation. Whereas the Minister of Finance here has relieved the tax burden on businesses and individuals, I urge the provincial Minister of Finance not to pick up that slack and impose from the provincial side a tax burden on our people.
I compliment the Minister of Finance on a budget that has been well received across Canada. I know it will be a stimulus to our economy and our people.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I could not help but listen to the member give us a great big speech about how he admires the budget that was brought down by the minister. I, on the other hand, did not see anything good about the budget.
I received hundreds of letters from my constituents. I received just as many telephones calls from my constituents. They are asking for one thing: get some sense back into the budget and, if not, why doesn't this government not resign or why doesn't it call an election?
One thing the hon. member did not talk about is something that is very sensitive to me as a member of Parliament from Toronto. I am referring to what was in the paper today: "Ottawa seeks private tenders on two Pearson terminals". We have seen what this government did when it came to power in 1984. It took CN Express which was losing money. Then it gave it away and privatized it. It was sold for $29 million. What did the people who inherited this white elephant do? They went
March 11, 1992

to the bank and they said: "Mr. Banker, we want to borrow some money". The bank looked it over and said: "Don't worry about it. We are going to give you close to $200 million on the land and on the assets of the company".
What was the end result? These people who took over this institution which was in existence since 1930 drove it into bankruptcy. Hundreds of employees, some 3,700 employees, were let go. Their pension funds were dealt in and we saw charges by the RCMP.
I am questioning whether this will be the same situation. It states that 3,200 jobs would be created. Now I am questioning myself on how the privatization of two terminals would create 3,200 jobs. The real answer is that it is not going to create 3,200 jobs. The other thing is-

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Oh, oh.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: I have five minutes, five minutes for questions and comments.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Yes, but if you want an answer you will have to conclude your question.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: I will put my question. After Canadian taxpayers spent millions of dollars on renovations to terminal 1 and terminal 2, doesn't the member across the way agree with me that they are going to give the two terminals away to some consortium only to benefit themselves? They are going to give these two terminals away to some consortium that supported the Conservatives during their first and second election bids.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in answer to your question to the member, no, he does not want an answer. He wants to make a speech. That is all right. I do not mind that.
The first part of his question dealt with the budget and spoke to the fact that I was so enthusiastic about it. I simply point out to him that I was talking to one of his own colleagues a day or two later. I met him in one of the buildings here. It was during Question Period and I said: "Listen, aren't you going to go down there and harangue the Minister of Finance on his budget?" He said: "No, I am not going to do that. That was a good budget". That was one of his own colleagues so he had better confer
The Budget
with his colleagues and maybe get a second opinion about the budget.
The second part was about the airport. He asked: "Are you going to privatize this and let individual people benefit from it?" Tell me, what is the market system all about? Is it a crime to make a profit? Is this the new philosophy of the Liberal Party, that if it is government owned people will not benefit, but if it is privately owned people will benefit? It seems to me that the beauty of the market system in North America is that everybody benefits if the market system works properly. Why would the member be against that?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Inuktitut]

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak in today's budget debate. The February 25 budget was really a "do-little" budget. After several years of big budget takes from taxpayers, the government's most recent budget gives a little but only a little. What it gives is so small the impact will be negligible, especially in my own constituency.
The budget provides some small assistance to mining companies, but the measures will, according to the Yukon Chamber of Mines, only benefit existing mines. There is no major boost to stimulate the exploration which is really needed in the north. Since the Canadian Exploration Incentive Program was cancelled by this current government in February 1990, mining exploration levels in the north have dropped substantially. The high Canadian dollar has also affected exploration levels.
In 1988, when the flow-through share incentive was in place, about $50 million in exploration was done in Yukon. Last year only $16 million was spent. This year the Chamber of Mines expects to see only about $5 million or $6 million spent in exploration.
In the Northwest Territories the outlook is similar. Small exploration companies could have used a break. For small business at least there are no tax increases.
There is a small increase in a lending program for small business, but it is really nothing significant. In the Northwest Territories there were 13 more bankruptcies in 1991 than there were in 1990. Now, 13 may not seem

March 11, 1992
The Budget
like a lot, but in the Northwest Territories one has to understand that there are not as many businesses as there would be down here.
Throughout Canada, and particularly in northern Canada, we were looking for a major commitment to infrastructure and we did not get it. In fact the federal Minister of Northern Affairs in media interviews following the release of the budget ruled out a major commitment to northern infrastructure because it would be too expensive. He said high costs in the north make it hard for the federal government to justify spending big amounts of money on northern transportation. That attitude merely demonstrates the shortsightedness of this current federal government.
Without the necessary basic infrastructure, the economies of the territories do not have a chance of becoming self-sufficient.
To paraphrase a former Conservative finance minister, the short-term pain of investing now in the north would bring long-term gain to all of Canada. High costs are a fact of life in northern Canada. The federal government must be prepared to deal with these costs so that northern Canada can be dealt into the Canadian economy as a contributing partner. The longer the federal government waits, the higher the infrastructure costs will become.
The north's infrastructure needs are not going to go away. They will only increase with time. By taking action now this government could reduce future costs.
I hope the government is not waiting for a northern megaproject in the belief that private enterprise will do what the government is not prepared to do for northerners. The north does not want a megaproject economy. It does not want a boom and bust economy. The north wants a community based, diversified economy, but it is getting no help from this federal government.
I hope the government is not waiting for the settlement of the TFN land claim in the hope that the settlement moneys will be used to address some of the needs it is currently ignoring. The land claim settlement is an obligation to Inuit over and above what the regular federal obligations are to all northerners.
When the leader of the Government of the Northwest Territories spoke at the First Ministers' conference on
the economy last month, she pointed out that the employment rate in the Northwest Territories has dropped by 3 per cent since 1989. Spending in the NWT has fallen 15 per cent since 1989. She pointed out that a federal commitment to the north infrastructure would mean not only more jobs for northerners but jobs for people in southern Canada as well.
A Conference Board of Canada study has estimated that for every job created in the north another 1.7 jobs are created elsewhere to support it.
All Canadians would benefit from increased federal investment in the north.
Members of the government would have us believe there is a significant tax cut in this budget. That is hardly the case. First of all, the cut is to the federal surtax which is a tax the Conservative government imposed on top of the basic federal income tax. Basic federal income taxes are not cut in this budget. The surtax will be reduced by 1 per cent on July 1 and it will be reduced by a further 1 per cent on January 1, 1993. Over an 11-month period the surtax will be reduced from its current level of 5 per cent to 3 per cent.
We appreciate this tax relief even though it is minimal, but we have not forgotten that there was no surtax before the Conservatives came to power. The government wants people to be grateful that the surtax is being reduced from 5 per cent to 3 per cent. The people know that next January they will still be paying a federal surtax of 3 per cent, a tax they did not pay before this government was elected. They know that this tax is just one of a total of 33 tax increases, including the GST, imposed on them by the Conservatives since they came to power in 1984.
Look at the actual savings to taxpayers of the surtax reduction. A table on page 135 of the government's own budget papers sets out the impact of the surtax reduction. The biggest benefits go to those who earn the most.
For example, a single taxpayer earning $15,000 a year now pays $66 in surtax. That individual's surtax will be reduced by $7 in 1992 and $27 in 1993. A single taxpayer earning $75,000 now pays $966 in surtax. That individual's surtax will be reduced by $80 in 1992 and $318 in 1993.
March 11, 1992

A one-eamer couple with two children earning $40,000 a year will have their surtax reduced by $27 in 1992 and $110 in 1993. A one-eamer couple with two children earning $75,000 a year will have their surtax reduced by $74 in 1992 and $297 in 1993.
A $7 reduction for the single person earning $15,000 and a $27 reduction for a couple with two children earning $40,000 is peanuts in my constituency. Seven dollars is just slightly more than the price of a litre of milk in most communities in my riding. Seven dollars does not buy very much in the major cities of southern Canada, but it buys far, far less in remote northern communities.
My constituents pay twice and three times as much as southern Canadians for basic goods, including groceries. The surtax reduction is better than no reduction at all, but it is not as good as no surtax at all. Its impact on low income earners in general is minimal and its impact on low income earners in the north is next to nothing.
Working Canadians and their employers are also paying more this year in unemployment insurance premiums. On July 1, 1991 the employee rate was increased from $2.25 to $2.80 per $100 of insurable earnings.
In January of this year, the employee rate was further increased to $3 and the employer rate was set at $4.20. The increase in the premium rate amounts to an additional $1 per week for employees whose insurable earnings are $26,000. Such employees will actually pay more for their premiums this year than they will get back under the surtax reduction.
Potential home buyers now have the opportunity to use their RRSPs to purchase a home. This is basically a good idea, and it was suggested by the Leader of the Opposition long before the budget was tabled by the Minister of Finance. However there are problems with this proposal as well. This plan runs only for a year and only benefits those who have RRSPs. Only those people who are working are in a position to contemplate buying a home.
How many of the 1.5 million unemployed Canadians will this plan benefit? How many northerners will this plan benefit? This proposal will only benefit those who live in areas where there is a housing market. This may seem self-evident in southern Canada where housing
The Budget
markets are taken for granted, but throughout most of northern Canada there is no housing to buy.
A severe housing crisis exists in the north. Affordability is an issue, but availability is a major problem. With the exception of a few larger communities there is no private housing market. The housing shortage results in overcrowding. Houses in the NWT are more crowded than in the rest of Canada. They are more crowded in the eastern Arctic than in the rest of the NWT. Since private housing is not affordable or available, social housing is the only alternative for many people.
Two weeks ago the Inuit Tapirisat of Canada made an excellent submission to the House of Commons aboriginal affairs committee on the issue of housing. It pointed out that in the eastern Arctic social housing cost-shared by the federal government is the only option available to the 80 per cent of the population who do not have housing provided by an employer.
Housing conditions in the north are nowhere near housing conditions in southern Canada. Funding currently provided for housing in the north is not sufficient to bring northern housing to the level of southern housing. The social housing budget for the north must be increased.
Yet, in the federal budget, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation was cut back. The growth in social housing expenditures will be limited to 3 per cent through to 1997. In 1990 $91 million was available for new units. The government has reduced that amount to $70 million in 1992-93 and to $45 million in subsequent years until 1996. This amounts to a cut of over 50 per cent in just three years.
In addition this government has eliminated the co-operative housing program. These cuts are occurring despite the fact that CMHC's social housing budget currently reaches only 6 per cent of Canadians and 15 per cent of Canadians, over one million people, are still in need of social housing.
The increase in the child care deduction will benefit some people, which is good. However, the deduction only benefits those who are paying income tax and the more someone earns the more value it has for them.
Women not currently working outside the home will not benefit from this and their opportunities to work outside the home were not increased by this budget.

March 11, 1992
The Budget
The budget did nothing to alleviate the serious shortage in day care spaces throughout the north and the whole of Canada. A severe day care space shortage exists in the north. There are no measures in the budget to alleviate this shortage. Despite repeated promises by the current Conservative government to provide more child care spaces, this budget has proved that these promises are dead. There will be no national day care program. The Minister of Health and Welfare has confirmed this. Once again we have broken promises.
This budget provides no hope for the unemployed. There is no job creation and the budget itself projects that unemployment levels will remain high.
The Northwest Territories is currently in a financial squeeze. The NWT government is cutting back because the federal government has cut its transfers to the territorial government. Unemployment is rising and this budget provides no help. This budget provides no hope for the poor and the hungry.
A couple of weeks ago a 41-year old single mother from Baker Lake in my constituency took it upon herself to raise money for the poor and hungry of her community. Baker Lake has a population of about 1,200 and an unemployment rate of about 85 per cent. Susan Toolook-took walked 50 miles through freezing temperatures, minus 38 degrees, and endured a blizzard which turned her planned three day journey into a week's journey. She raised more than $2,000. Donations have apparently not only come from the residents of Baker Lake and other NWT communities but from Vancouver, Toronto, Saskatchewan and elsewhere.
She said that she did it for the less fortunate because the costs of basic necessities such as food and hunting supplies is often too high for most people. She said that she did it for the people who sometimes do not have any food to feed their children, for those who can never find jobs, and for those who are actually working but are finding it hard to buy the things they need to keep alive or the equipment necessary for hunting because they are too expensive.
In this community some children and their parents go to bed hungry. It saddens me to say it, but hunger is a fact of life for many children and people throughout the north.
I would like to quote a document that was adopted by the United Nations on November 20, 1989, entitled: "Your Rights as Children of the World". It says that one of those rights is the right to adequate nutrition, shelter
and medical care. Our Prime Minister was one of the signatories of this document.
I want to recognize Susan Toolooktook for her courage and caring. I wish the federal government cared half as much as she does.
Just before Christmas the Prime Minister ratified the document I just quoted, the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child. That declaration says that children should not go hungiy. That declaration is being contravened in our very own country.
Canada must live up to its commitments in that declaration by eradicating the hunger and poverty in our midst.
The government's proposed new child benefits package could be a start in that direction. It is supposed to come into effect in January 1993. The Minister of National Health and Welfare will be discussing implementation of this benefit with his provincial and territorial counterparts and other interested parties. I will reserve judgment on the real value of this benefit until more details are available.
I do want to say that I regret that a national day care program was the government's price for this package. I am sorry the day care program was sacrificed because I believe that the children of Canada and their mothers need more child care support as well as increased child benefits. It is too bad the government made these issues into an either-or situation.
Major changes are needed to the formula financing transfer payments to the territorial governments. However, this budget did not announce any changes and that is rather disappointing. Two years ago the federal government imposed a new financing arrangement on the territories reducing funding to them and the consequences are unfair.
Under the formula, the Government of the Northwest Territories loses $1.20 for every dollar it raises. This is clearly regressive and the Government of the Northwest Territories is currently negotiating with the federal government seeking adjustments to the formula.
Recently the federal government announced increases to the transfer payments to the provinces. I urge this government to be as forthcoming with the territories.
Green plan funding has suffered another set-back in this budget. The original green plan program announced in December 1990 was funded by $3 billion over five years.
March 11, 1992

In last year's budget the government decided to spread that funding over six years instead of five. This year's budget reduces the green plan by $150 million over the next two years, although the government does say that it will spend that money later. Given this government's record of broken promises, why should we believe it? There are also cuts to the Department of Indian and Northern Affairs and other areas, such as education.
Mr. Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence in allowing me to say what I have to say.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to compliment my colleague on his summary of the budget and his comments on those areas adversely affected in his region of the Northwest Territories, the eastern Arctic, Iqaluit.
The government is always challenging this side of the House saying that we only criticize and never put forward ideas about how to improve the situation or make it better. We are constantly putting forward ideas on this side of the House but it seems that they always fall on deaf ears. That can be the frustration of having ideas in opposition.
However, one of the areas that I think even the government would not refute is that of tourism. Tourism is one area that can galvanize this country. It is one area that can give us back the feeling of dignity and pride as Canadians that we need to have so desperately in this country. I do not care what region you are from, that is an essential requirement today because of the economic disaster that touches all of us and tends to depress us.
The area that my colleague comes from is one of the environmental heavens of the planet. It has a potential for environmental tourism beyond imagination. I would like to ask my colleague if he feels that the government was once again negligent in not paying attention to that potential to not only promote spirit and pride but also to generate more foreign exchange which would improve the quality of life for Canadians in the north and make us all feel proud of the nation as a whole.
I wonder if my colleague could comment on the environmental tourism potential which the government has ignored?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I would just like to say one thing before I get on to explaining how we can benefit from a tourism marketing strategy by this government. That is, it does not really help us very much in our tourism potential when every day for two and one-half months we have 24
The Budget
hours of sunlight and the Minister of the Environment is telling us that we should be telling our kids to stay inside. That basically tells us that we should stay inside our house for two and one-half months, during the best two and one-half months of the whole year.
In terms of potential for the north, it is there. We have national parks, bird sanctuaries, great fishing, sports hunting and specialized tours in the north. However, there have been some problems in the last three or four years where the tourism potential has been severely cut back because of measures that were introduced in terms of the GST and others and the high cost of travel in the north.
When you add whatever taxes have been added since the time this government has been in power, that travel has been severely restricted. I know, because before I got elected as a member of Parliament I used to operate a tourism company in my hometown of Rankin Inlet.
We used to have people coming up from southern Ontario. We had people from the Federation of Ontario Naturalists. We had people coming by VIA Rail from Winnipeg. We had people coming from Horizon Tours. We had people coming through Fiesta Holidays.
But in the last few few years we have not had that. People are not travelling as much because of the high cost of travel and because of the imposition of further taxes either on the fare itself or the increase in fare because of having to pay more for the services, gas, or whatever to operate the trains or planes and whatnot.
I thank my colleague for asking that question because the potential is there. I know it, he knows it and I am sure that most of my colleagues on this side of the House know it because we were in Iqaluit for a caucus meeting.
I invite any member of this House to come to Whitehorse next week for the Arctic winter games. I cannot remember the exact date, but I urge members from this side of the House and the other side to come to Whitehorse and see the Arctic winter games as well as to contribute to the economy of the north.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Suzanne Duplessis (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister for External Relations and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for External Relations; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to participate in the debate today on the federal budget for 1992. I am pleased with the concrete measures that were announced and with the realistic approach of this budget.

March 11, 1992
The Budget
Allow me to congratulate the Minister of Finance. This budget shows once again that the minister listens to the people, is aware of the economic difficulties that Canadians must face and, above all, uses imagination and a realistic approach to come up with solutions which, in the short and medium term, will accelerate economic recovery and restore public confidence.
I also want to point out the excellent work done by the previous Minister of Finance. Indeed, starting in 1984, that minister took initiatives that now enable the government to take positive measures. Today, more than ever before, I am convinced that we were right in defending an economic recovery plan aimed at controlling government expenses and, therefore, the deficit once and for all.
Mr. Speaker, like any Canadian family, the government cannot use credit forever. It is easy to always borrow more; in fact it is a lot easier than to take unpopular measures.
But there comes a time when you have to pay your bills. That time came in 1984 when we formed the government. The situation in public finances was appalling. The federal government was simply living above its means.
However, thanks to very tight controls and sound management practices since 1984, our government was able to announce a tax reduction in this budget. This is certainly very good news for everybody. Moreover, this tax reduction is not reckless borrowing or passing on the debt to others, but rather a rigorous control of the government administration. Once again, we succeed by cutting government expenditures; the salaries for the Prime Minister and cabinet members were reduced by 5 per cent, those of all members of Parliament were frozen; we eliminated, consolidated, deferred or privatized a total of 46 government agencies; we cut operating costs in various departments, etc.
We are also tightening our belts and we require government services to do the same, making sure however that service to the public is not affected.
I now come to an important part of the budget, the family assistance programs. I am one of those who believes that families form the social fabric of our society and that we should do everything possible to help them.
I was among those who appealed to the Minister of Finance to take the necessary steps in order to do away with the injustice which prevailed for many years because married couples with children and unmarried couples with children were not subject to the same taxation.
In the present budget, the minister recognized our demand and corrected that situation. From now on, all couples, married or not, will be treated equally.
This certainly shows how high a priority we place on families from Quebec and from all over Canada. However, the commendable initiatives of the Minister of Finance did not stop there. He announced a complete restructuring of the family allowance and child tax credit systems so that parents will now receive a single non-taxable monthly benefit of up to $144.
This is certainly good news for low income families because it represents an increase of the annual amount they receive and furthermore, they will get their money monthly. They will no longer have to wait for weeks before they can use it and they can budget accordingly.
On that same subject, and in accordance with our government's policy regarding assistance to families, the child care expense deduction has been raised significantly-
This measure will help traditional families but will also greatly help the one parent families. In that area, there is a fact that no one can deny; most single parent families are headed by women. Many of them have the total responsibility for the education of the children and for all other parental activities. A study published in the papers on February 24 showed that poverty strikes hard at many one parent families that, in most, cases have a young woman at their head.
During the 1980s, the number of one parent families skyrocketed in Canada. At the last census, there were 252,680 single parent families in Quebec; that is 21 per cent of all families with children. What is most troubling is that in 1989, in Quebec, 40 per cent of the families headed by a woman were considered poor. Our government is very conscious of those social problems and the changes in fiscal deductions are certainly proof of that. Also, a great many families hope to buy their first house, again, it is often in order to find a better environment for bringing up children. The purchase of a home is, for the majority of people, the most important investment of their lives. Sometimes though, they need help if their dream is to come true. That is the purpose of our home buyer's plan which allows the owners of a RRSP to
March 11, 1992

withdraw up to $20,000 from it in order to buy their first house.
This initiative certainly helps families, but it also fulfils another purpose, that is revive the home building industry. As they say in French-"Quand le bdtiment va, tout va". If we give those who own a RRSP the possibility to use it for that specific purpose, we will encourage job creation in a number of home-building related industries; we will stimulate the building industry itself and we will contribute to a quick and sustained recovery of the economy.
On budget night this announcement was welcomed enthusiastically by everyone. I am sure the results will be visible soon and will have a positive impact throughout the country.
Canadians want to work, but we cannot make it happen by creating a paper recovery, a recovery based on injecting borrowed money into the economy. What we need is a real recovery, not an artificial one, and I am very confident about the measures contained in this budget.
In addition to helping the construction industry and families, the government has also tabled proposals to help business. The capital cost allowance rate has been raised from 25 to 30 per cent, and $230 million in new money will be committed to research and development. The ceiling for loans under the Small Business Loans Act has been increased to $200,000, and business owners who are temporarily in financial difficulty will be able to obtain financing more easily.
To meet international competition as we enter the 21st century, businesses must be able to purchase the most technically advanced equipment available in order to produce high quality goods at the lowest possible cost.
Having been Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Science and Technology from 1987 to 1991, I can appreciate the importance of investing in more efficient machinery. This budget will make it possible to meet this fundamental requirement. The positive impact of these measures, Mr. Speaker, is a foregone conclusion. If small businesses improve their cash flow, sooner or later they will be able to expand and create new jobs. That is the recipe for genuine economic recovery-not a paper or
The Budget
artificial recovery but a genuine, sound and, above all, durable recovery.
This budget is realistic. While its ultimate goal remains reducing the deficit, which is undeniably the answer to all our problems, the budget has taken an innovative approach and proposes specific measures directed at all Canadians. We did not want to play favourites. We included everyone. This budget is fair to all Canadians. The Minister of Finance should take a bow. This is a serious and realistic budget and a perfect response to the challenges Canada must meet.
Mr. Speaker, I intend to vote for these budgetary measures, and I say so with great enthusiasm.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
When the member talks about this budget being a fair budget, and she went through a list of some of the things that this budget will do, we should be very careful not to mislead Canadians. Most of the budget measures the member talked about really do not kick in until 1993.1 had some people come in to my constituency all excited about this family plan which by and large I think is pretty good. But you must tell them that it is not until 1993. You have to be careful that you are not creating a false expectation there.
My question has to do with the people who are unemployed, the 1.5 million who we still have recorded and the other two million who are on welfare or some other form of social assistance. The problem that I have when I listen to members of the government is they tend to pat the Minister of Finance on the back and pat themselves on the back for this great budget. There are parts of the budget that I think are responsible and I will give them that. But we keep forgetting in this House that we are not here to look out for those people who are advantaged. We are here to look out for those who are disadvantaged. I, for the life of me, cannot find what good or what specific program in this budget will help the three million people who are out of work.
I would like the hon. member to tell me what she says to her constituents who are unemployed, are on welfare or social assistance and how this budget will help them.

The Budget

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for External Relations; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate this question from my hon. colleague opposite, the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood. I want to tell him that Canadians who are unemployed or on welfare can place great hopes in this budget because it provides strong foundations for recovery.
We have taken several initiatives since 1984, including an increased emphasis on training so that people are better qualified to take up new jobs, be it in high-tech areas or elsewhere. We have asked our industries to improve their productivity and facilitated their achievement of this goal. We have also facilitated the emergence of new high tech-businesses, supported the pharmaceutical sector as well as research and taken steps such as creating excellence centres to ensure the immediate communication of research results across the country.
We have taken all kinds of steps, including some regarding financial matters to facilitate a number of things, thus laying strong foundations on which to build the future so that, in the years ahead, Canadians can compete internationally and globally.
My colleague says that we pat ourselves on the back for this great budget. Personally, Mr. Speaker, I must say that I do find it excellent because we listened carefully to Canadians. We carried out public consultations and Canadians have asked for the following. They want realistic, lasting solutions to our economic problems, not quick fixes. They want us to cut the deficit. They want government streamlined and made less wasteful. They want opportunities to improve their skills. They want steps taken to ensure that our social programs meet their basic needs. Most of all, they want a renewed basis for confidence.
So here is what we have done. We have substantially reduced the deficit. We are cutting spending and taxes. We will restructure and streamline the operations of government. We will increase support for research and development. We will reduce the tax burden for the manufacturing and processing sectors. We will help small business. We will simplify and substantially enrich our support programs for families and children. We will assist Canadians with registered retirement savings plans to buy a home. We will increase our support for Canadians with disabilities.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: I am sorry for interrupting, but the five minutes are up.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a real pleasure to participate in the debate here today on the budget and to speak on behalf of the people of Macleod.
It is an important debate on an important budget. This budget is consistent. It is realistic. It is sensible and, above all, it is fair.
I would like to touch on each of these points. I would also like to discuss how this budget affects the people in the province of Alberta and the people in the constituency of Macleod which I serve.
The first thing to note about the budget is its consistency. Perhaps this was the most difficult budget for this government since it was elected in 1984. We know some Canadians, we heard this from a small minority, called on the government to abandon its policy of fiscal restraint. They asked for higher government spending at the expense of a higher deficit. They wanted to shift greater costs on to the shoulders of our children.
They were a vocal and a sadly misguided minority. They did not speak for a majority of sensible Canadians. A majority of Canadians asked the government to maintain the fight against the deficit.
I met with many constituents in the months prior to the budget. They told me above anything else to continue the fight against the deficit. Certainly a majority of my constituents want the government to continue with its policy of fiscal restraint. In this way, the budget is fully consistent with the fiscal prudence of the seven previous Progressive Conservative national budgets.
Not only is the budget consistent, but it is also realistic. It does not offer the quick fix or shortcuts to prosperity that some would have us provide. Some would have us believe that is possible. History proves that just is not possible. It just does not work. The reality is that Canada's debt is over $400 billion. The reality is that the budget deficit will be down to $27.5 billion in 1992-93 and dropping year by year after that. The reality is that the Government of Canada should no longer need to borrow money after the mid-1990s. My constituents continue to encourage the government to look for ways to reduce spending. They know that increased spending means increased deficit and increased taxes. They find that to be unacceptable. They know that reduced spending means a reduced deficit. This budget responds to those concerns. A $1 billion cut in spending in this
March 11, 1992

budget for 1992-93 is a realistic response to the needs of the country today.
The budget is also realistic because it is sensitive to Canada's current economic situation. It provides a framework for a lasting recovery.
The Minister of Finance had to deal with these realities in preparing this budget. In the face of very difficult economic times, he has done very well, just as those of us from Alberta would have expected.
The budget is sensible. It offers some sensible solutions to the problems that Canada faces today. For example, on the question of streamlining of government, small business people in my riding tell me, and I know from having been a business person before getting into public life, there is just too much red tape in the dealings with the federal government. I know that all other members in the House will have heard that as well. The sensible thing to do is to streamline. Cut duplication and make government more efficient and easier to deal with for business people. The budget takes those steps. Those are sensible steps.
It makes it easier for small business to deal with government. It makes it easier for small business people to stay in business and to contribute to creating new jobs, new economic opportunities and leading the way to economic recovery.
This is a fair budget. It gives taxpayers a break through a reduction in the income surtax. Every Canadian taxpayer benefits. Across the board cuts ensures that all Canadians are treated fairly.
The budget also addresses an area of fairness which I have been concerned with for some time, the treatment of families under the tax system. Many people in my riding of Macleod wanted this situation changed. They felt that it was unfair that the traditional family unit was being penalized by the tax systems.
Many other members of my caucus from Alberta also realize the unfairness of the situation. A caucus committee was formed and under the guidance of my colleague the member for Calgary North, a series of recommendations were made this past autumn. This is from the
The Budget
family caucus. The finance minister listened and made some of the recommendations aspects of the budget we are currently debating. Fairness has been restored in this area.
This is another good example. People often ask how one member of Parliament can have any positive impact on the Government of Canada. Well, here is a good example. Members of the Alberta caucus are effective representatives of our province and as chair of the Alberta caucus, I am proud of our contributions to this budget. I thank the Minister of Finance, who happens to come from Vegreville, for having listened to his colleagues from Alberta.
He has also listened to all Canadians. The budget is the product of consultation over a period of months. Albertans as well as Canadians from other provinces played a very important role in those consultations. The finance minister travelled across the country and he listened.
As well, I worked in my constituency listening to the people from Macleod. I heard many suggestions in phone calls and letters I received daily. As you might imagine, the people of Macleod are more than willing to offer useful advice, something that is true, I am sure, in all other constituencies. I took that advice and I passed it along to the minister. The minister listened and this is the result.
What did I hear? I have touched on some of the points already, but let me just hit the highlights. The people of Macleod told me that above all else, continue the fight against the deficit. They want this government to stand firm and not give in to pressure to increase spending at the cost of a higher deficit. They want realistic solutions. They realize there are no quick fixes, no shortcuts to facing the economic problems we have.
Albertans have asked for a leaner, more responsive federal government. In fact, it is true that they have asked for the same thing from provincial governments as well. The federal government is listening and we are working hard on that.
People want a government that does more with less. Small business people tell me there is too much red tape

The Budget
and duplication when dealing with the federal government. The budget responds to all of these concerns.
What are people saying about this? Here is one example. A businessman from Lundbreck, Alberta sent me a fax shortly after the budget came out. It read: "I am very pleased to see the budget highlights. It is exactly what we had hoped for in the direction it has taken. Keep up the good work".
The Calgary Chamber of Commerce issued a news release that read in part: "There are some good signs of leadership in today's budget, such as no tax increases. A decrease in the surtax, a child tax credit increase of $1,000, a capital cost allowance increase from 25 to 30 per cent for manufacturing and processing equipment and a $20,000 RRSP homeowner loan are all conducive to mildly stimulating spending. The 5 per cent rollback in minister's salaries, although modest in dollar terms, is also symbolically important".
Mr. Speaker, I know that my time here is quickly coming to a close, but I want to let you and all members of the House know that I stand firmly behind this budget. I believe it has come about as a result of thorough consultation with Canadians. It is contributing to a stronger economy. It is contributing to the recovery of the economy in Canada and it continues to supply the kind of leadership this country needs.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened to the member from Alberta who praised his fellow colleague, the finance minister, on his budget.
I have spoken several times during this budget debate and I have to say that I cannot praise it. I have been here a long time and the Minister of Finance has been in this House a long time. I heard him, when he sat on this side of the House, criticizing budgets.
I am sure he understands why we have to criticize this minister's budget. There is nothing in it for ordinary Canadians.
The ordinary Canadian today is looking at Parliament and asking what goes on here. Why is this not a flexible enough institution to deal with the every day problems that are afflicting ordinary Canadians' every day lives.
I say that because he talked about fairness. Where is the fairness to the unemployed? Where is the fairness to the small businesses that are going under daily across Canada? Where is the fairness in that there are no new incentives to create jobs?
There is no extra money to go into research and development and this country needs so much of that. We have all the expertise.
Let us look at fishing. We have over-capacity, we are told by the Minister of Fisheries, onshore and in the water. Yet we allow the foreigners to come in within our 200-mile limit when the jobs are there onshore to handle that fish.
There is nothing to put a new direction into the marketing of that fish. If the foreigners can come over here, catch the fish and eat it at home, why can we not catch it and sell it to them? It needs a bit of turnaround by this government to see the opportunity that is there for us.
I ask the hon. member this question. Where is the fairness from the government's side to the people in Canada who are homeless, hungry and who have been unemployed for the first time probably in all their working lives. Where is the fairness in this budget that the member is talking about?
Where is the creativeness that is needed which we are not seeing from this government? Where is the creativeness to get Canada going again?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to respond to the points made by the hon. member for South West Nova and I appreciate her intervention.
She should know that I would be a little bit out of my depth spending a lot of time talking about fishing, having not a great number of fishermen or people involved in the fishing industry in the riding of Macleod.
Let me deal with the question of fairness head on. The hon. member asks about fairness. What this government is providing is a fair economic climate that allows everybody the opportunity to take advantage of the opportunities that are there. Let us look at the interest rate policies that have brought us the lowest interest rates we have had in nearly two decades.
Let us take a look at the training programs that this government has put in place. I am sure they are taken advantage of in the hon. member's riding as they are in my riding. There are parts of my riding where there is chronic unemployment, and we have taken a creative look at the way in which training programs should work.
March 11, 1992

We have taken a creative look at the ways we should assist people in chronically underemployed areas and I must say that it has resulted in significant opportunities in the Crowsnest Pass area. In fact, what has resulted is the opening of a new plant, Strand Industries with a considerable amount of assistance from the Government of Canada.
These are Canadians who have faith in the opportunities that are there, that are marketing internationally, that are looking for things to do, that are looking out, that are not part of the doom and gloom that the CBC and my colleagues opposite would have us all believe is bringing us to the end of this country. These are the people who are taking the opportunities.
There are many other examples but I see I am getting the eye from the Speaker so I will sit down.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able finally to take the floor as a full participant in this budget debate As finance critic of the Bloc Quebecois, I cannot help pointing out the democratic deficit in this House, which seems to me to be as chronic as the government's budget deficit.
Forty-one major statements have already been made during the first three days of the budget debate, not one of them by a member of our party. Parliamentary democracy in the House of Commons is practically as sick as the federal government's finances, Mr. Speaker.
In spite of that, I can assure you that I will continue to be present, to demand fair treatment and to defend Quebec's interests. We know the political legitimacy of our party in Quebec and we know that after the next election, there will be more than 60 of us to express Quebec's interests even more strongly.
Until that day comes, and I hope it is soon, let us look at the February 25 budget. All in all, this budget got a better reception than any of Michael Wilson's, at least for a few hours, while the Minister of Finance got an initial media reaction that was not too disastrous.
The Budget
The day after, the rather moderate earlier comments were heard less often. Two days after, the Canadian dollar started another slide that the Bank of Canada is still trying to stop with a gradual increase in interest rates.
The Minister of Finance wanted to leave the public with a first impression of a government that had managed to reduce the deficit while lowering income taxes slightly. But this first impression gave way as analysts and ordinary citizens learned what was really in the budget.
The camouflage lasted only a day and the disenchantment will last all year. Why such disenchantment? First, because all agree that the budget's economic forecasts are too optimistic. This government has a habit of announcing that it sees light at the end of the tunnel. The problem is that the tunnel is getting longer every week, every month, every year.
Indeed, if this government's budget forecasts since it came to power had been realized, we would already have a budget surplus, although the projected deficit for next year is still $27.5 billion. We all know that this estimate will be exceeded.
Let us quickly compare the finance minister's forecasts with the data now available. In his budget of February 25, the minister expects business investment to grow by 0.5 per cent in 1992. However, on February 28, three days later, Statistics Canada published the results of its business survey and predicts that business investment will decline by 1.5 per cent.
Concerning the labour market, the budget predicts an increase of the work force, a higher number of jobs and a decrease in the unemployment rate, to 10.1 per cent. On March 6, 10 days after the budget, Statistics Canada announced for February a decrease of the work force, a decrease in jobs and a higher unemployment rate which rose to 10.6 per cent. In fact, there were 3,000 fewer jobs in February at the worst part of the recession.
The budget predicts for 1992 a continued decrease of interest rates, down to an average of 6.9 per cent for short term and 8.5 per cent for long term. During the last few weeks, we have seen the interset rates rise; they are now at 7.85 per cent for shot term and at 9.1 per cent for long term. The dollar is still going down and there is a chance the interest rates will keep increasing if the

March 11, 1992
The Budget
Governor of the Bank of Canada maintains his suicidal policy.
The budget predicts a vigorous recovery of residential investments with an 11.9 per cent increase. On March 9, two days ago, only 13 days after the budget, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation announced that the market had not reacted at all to the lower interest rates of the last few months and that the slight increase in construction starts we observed in Febuaiy for the whole of Canada was due to the high number of social housing projects launched in Ontario thanks to the budget of the Ontario government so strongly criticized by the federal Minister of Finance.
According to me, it is useless to go on with this analysis of the minister's predictions. They are already outdated and, as always, the economy is worse than expected and the deficit will be higher than anticipated.
Why such a disastrous outlook, Mr. Speaker? Because the government rejects the most powerful tool it could use to stimulate the economy: the monetary policy. Even though there is no convincing sign of economic recovery, the governor of the Bank of Canada is sticking to a policy of high interest rates, an ultra-conservative and suicidal behaviour in the present circumstances. The fight against inflation has been over for months and the Canadian dollar must come down to a level where the Canadian economy can be really competitive. Economists seem to agree that such a level should be between 75 and 80 U.S. cents.
The financial sector has already nicknamed the governor of the Bank of Canada Rambo because of his merciless fight against inflation which has resulted in 1.5 million unemployed in Canada. Even Rambo stops when the war is over, but not Mr. Crow. To him, high interest rates and a high dollar are a religion. The financial sector had to find a new name to describe his suicidal blend of religion and monetary policy. He is now known as the Bank of Canada's ayatollah.
Mr. Speaker, nothing in the finance minister's speech leads us to believe that he will exercise his statutory responsibilities and put an end to this policy which is a disaster for our economy. On the contrary, he has only praise for his monetary policy's ayatollah. They practise
the same ultra-conservative religion, convinced that they are right and everybody else is wrong.
With the inflation rate at 1.6 per cent, the real interest rates in Canada are 3 to 5 points above those in the United States, a level totally unbearable for the Canadian economy. When we talk about a lower deficit, Mr. Speaker, we must also look at recovery. When interest rates go down 1 per cent, the government can save more than $4 billion on the cost of servicing our enormous national debt. When there is a recovery and the unemployment rate goes down 1 per cent, the additional revenue for the Treasury as a result of this 1 per cent drop in unemployment totals $5 billion. We have to look at the impact on economic recovery, not just the cutbacks.
Are there more disappointments in this budget? Of course. Private citizens and businesses initially believed there would be a modest tax cut, as announced in the budget, but they were soon disillusioned. First of all, cutbacks in transfer payments to the provinces for health care and post-secondary education will make it practically impossible for provincial and municipal budgets to avoid tax increases.
For Quebec alone, the potential loss is nearly $2 billion for the coming year, while municipal taxes payable in April, which is quite soon, are substantially higher as a result of last year's cuts. Furthermore, the unemployment insurance account's deficit is expected to lead to another increase in employee and employer contributions in 1992, after a 32 per cent increase in 1991, since the government has withdrawn altogether from financing the unemployment insurance fund.
The prospects for tax relief have faded and will disappear altogether when provincial budgets are tabled at the end of April and in early May.
Once we analyse the few concrete measures in this budget, our disillusionment will be complete. First of all, we see the government abandoning its commitment to a genuine family policy, which it did without any consultation with the provinces, although we all know perfectly well that family policy is a fundamental issue, at least for Quebec. The family allowances system has been replaced by an income support plan for low-income families. This decision points to a significant change in values and a new concept of the role of the state in society,
March 11, 1992

especially with respect to the family, a concept that reflects an ultraconservative about-face, while there was no opportunity for a real debate on this issue.
The government is doing gradually and in a roundabout manner what voters would never tolerate if they knew exactly what was at stake. In the short term, families whose income is the equivalent of the average family income will receive a benefit on a level with benefits under the present system. However, since income levels will not be indexed, there will be a gradual erosion of the amounts available to families. As is the case for other measures already implemented by this government, the negative impact will be felt only gradually.
The changes involving unemployment insurance and the jobs strategy announced three years ago are a case in point.
When it tabled Bill C-21 on unemployment insurance reform, the Canadian government made a big promotional drive concerning its employment strategy with funds of $1.8 billion. On numerous occasions, the government promised that the unemployment insurance reform would not affect the funds targetted for the employment strategy.
The Minister of Finance remained silent on this issue in his speech. We had to wait for the tabling of the Estimates by the President of the Treasury Board two days later to find out that the funds for the strategy had been reduced to $1.3 billion. That represents a cut of $350 million compared to last year and $475 million compared to the original commitment.
The government is trying to make us believe that these cuts are compensated by supplementary funds for job training under the unemployment insurance program. In fact, the funds provided under the unemployment insurance program are only for those who are eligible to unemployment insurance benefits, which excludes all the workers who have been unemployed for a long time, as well as those already on welfare. Thus, the cuts in the funds for the employment strategy directly affect the programs for the have-nots that wanted to join the labour market again and were hoping to improve their lot.
The Budget
From now on, this responsibility will increasingly have to be borne by the provinces and municipalities, even though they do not have the necessary tax base to provide such help. This is a good example of the gradual consequences of the new programs implemented by this ultraconservative government. It is not the only example of unfulfilled promises. The fate of the co-op housing program is just as eloquent.
That program, which was originally at the experimental stage for five years, was the subject of an in-depth study in 1990 and, given its social usefulness and economic efficiency, eventually became a permanent program. The co-op groups, which were reassured as to the future of the program, undertook to submit concrete projects. Last December 17, the minister responsible for housing confirmed that the program was now permanent and he even announced a slight budget increase for 1992. Yet, in the budget speech, the Minister of Finance announced unequivocally the elimination of that program in order to make annual savings of $5 million, an amount which is 30 times less than the increase in the national defence budget. This is a brutal violation of a commitment renewed on the very eve of the budget. It is no wonder that people no longer any confidence in this government.
For Quebecers, there is another way of evaluating the performance of this government, and that is to see how it fulfils its responsibility regarding regional development. How is Quebec treated compared to other regions? Without considering the billions for western farmers and the hundreds of millions for fishermen who are in particular difficulty-I am only considering the regular budget funding to fight the imbalance in regional development in 1992, the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency receives $447 million, the Western Economic Diversification Department $301 million and Quebec $191 million. The Atlantic region gets 25.2 per cent more, the west 3 per cent more, while Quebec gets 18.3 per cent less.
Where were the defenders of Quebec's interests in this government when this budget was being prepared? According to any criteria of fairness, Mr. Speaker, Quebec is literally being robbed when it comes to regional development. For Quebec industries, especially those that do research and development, this budget continues to penalize them seriously. At the recent first ministers' conference, the Quebec finance minister asked the federal government to harmonize its taxation of research and development with Quebec's. Why? Because now, the federal government taxes back 39 per

March 11, 1992
The Budget
cent of Quebec government funding for companies that do research and development in Quebec.
How can that encourage Quebec's long-term economic development, when we know very well that the federal government's spending on research and development is concentrated very heavily in Ontario?
We Quebecers have only one consolation. In view of such a situation, the referendum on Quebec sovereignty in the fall of 1992 will finally give us a chance to get out of this madhouse, to take back all our taxes and to assume all our responsibilities.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to express my views on the budget that was brought down about a week ago, if I am not mistaken.

I have the privilege and honour to speak partly on behalf of the citizens and constituents in the Mount Royal riding as well as those people which one has the privilege and pleasure of meeting across this country in the role of member of Parliament. It is important for all of us to address this budget and to do it in a way that is somewhat analytical while at the same time perhaps a little philosophical.
We must be made aware of the fact that this budget we are addressing is clearly designed as a short-term budget. It is not based on the reality of the lifestyle and living conditions we find in our country, which is faced with an incredibly high rate of unemployment and is very unstable in terms of its sense of belonging, its sense of self and its place in an evolving society. The political interests of this government have never been so blatant as they are in this particular budget.
Serving that particular political interest is a great disservice to the long-term social, economic and cultural interests of this country. Let us be reminded of the fact that this government has constantly said that it is going to reduce the deficit. It has done little of that. This government has said that it is going to create jobs, jobs, jobs, and we know it has done very little of that.
This budget is deadly silent and puts nothing in place to prepare our society, our population, our workers to deal with the newly evolved society in which we find ourselves. The international world today is a globalized market, it is a post-industrial market, it is a high- tech world. We have not organized and have no industrial strategy to properly help our workers make the kinds of adjustments that are needed.
There are no adjustment measures in here. There are cuts in research and development. There are no mechanisms to aid the transition from old jobs to new, no training for the 1.5 million unemployed, let alone an attempt to address the problems facing the over two million Canadians now forced to live on welfare and the thousands of Canadians joining them every single week because there just are not jobs out there. Our economy is falling flat on its face.
This critique of what the government has done and has failed to do is just a short snapshot.
This government often says that the Official Opposition does very little except criticize, that it puts forward no new ideas or new projects. That is really not the role of an Official Opposition in this House. It is here to analyze what the government is doing and to make constructive observations on what the government is doing.
