In this case our party chose to make some very constructive suggestions as to what we should do just before the budget came up. As a matter of fact, at the end of January the Leader of the Official Opposition and the Liberal Party put before this government an emergency economic plan for its consideration in the creation of the budget.
It was thought about very carefully with the thought of addressing the deficit so that we would not add to the deficit in any significant way while at the same time put the country back to work. That economic and social balance is required.
As the Canadian economy was mired in the worst economic crisis since the great depression and we had not heard any specific plans or goals on the economy, to get the economy kick-started again, we put forward a plan of action in these tough economic times, in which it is so much harder for first-time home buyers to afford a down payment on a home, to help the weak housing market move forward and stop the negative spin-offs affecting the whole economy.
March 11, 1992

We also said that there were hundreds of towns and cities across Canada with infrastructure projects waiting only for adequate funding. We need a good, solid, healthy infrastructure if we want industry to come in and grow around that infrastructure and get the best of modern service. What is the point of high technology if we cannot move it after we have made the widget?
Many workers have lost their jobs permanently and lack the necessary skills to be competitive in the marketplace. This House will recognize the fact that 40 per cent of Canadians have difficulty with basic reading, writing and arithmetic and the illiteracy in our population must be addressed if we want to face that global competition and have a new prosperity, that famous new word this government loves to use.
There were two million Canadians and more 700,000 children relying on food banks in 1991. Someone has said that we have more food banks than we have McDonald's restaurants across this country right at the moment. We came up with a program, the elements of the one-year emergency plan I am going to outline as they were submitted by the Leader of the Official Opposition.
First, a 5 per cent minimum down payment for first-time homeowners. Lowering the required down payment from 10 per cent to 5 per cent would help boost the beleaguered housing industry and open up ownership to those who have never before had a chance to own their own home. The direct cost of that program to the taxpayers is zero.
Second, allow the use of RRSPs to finance first-time homes. I was a little bit leery when I first heard that but then I looked at how the RRSP was to be used. It was not the same as this government's approach which allows $20,000 each to buy any kind of home at any price. That is highly irresponsible, but our approach was very responsible. Our plan would help to stimulate the housing market, and it was endorsed by the Canadian Real Estate Association. In our plan the maximum allowable withdrawal would be limited to $7,500 which would go along with the 5 per cent down payment. The direct cost of this program to taxpayers was zero.
The Budget
Third, a shared cost infrastructure program. Funding for these projects would be shared one-third each, which is only fair and logical, between the three levels of government. The federal share would be $1 billion, and there would be a provincial and a municipal share. Half to two-thirds of the jobs created in these projects would be in construction and in manufacturing and 90 per cent of the materials required are manufactured in Canada.
Studies have shown that the net cost to the federal government, after considering increased tax revenues and decreased unemployment insurance payments and welfare payments, would be about $300 million. That $1 billion upfront cost would be funded through reduced debt service payments which would have resulted from lower than expected interest rates.
Fourth, intensified training initiatives. Canada is still one of the lowest per capita investors in training among the OECD countries. Then in this budget we went and cut anything that would lead to research and development or training.
The government must increase the scope and availability of basic skills programs and find new ways to get Canadian companies to invest in their workers. It just makes good sense to invest in one's workers. This $150 million program would be funded through the existing training programs cancelling the $20 million prosperity initiatives along the way-that road show is totally unnecessary-and reduced debt service payments. It was a very good initiative.
Fifth, emergency federal funding for food banks. In 1990 the federal government spent $67 million on advertising and millions and millions of dollars more on polling. If we redirected merely $25 million of this money to food banks we could help to provide immediate short-term relief to thousands of suffering Canadians. The direct additional cost of this program to taxpayers would also be zero. I would suggest that those were very positive suggestions. It is just regrettable that this government chose to ignore every single solitary one of them.
What did the government choose to do instead? There are many, but I just picked a few for your own information, Mr. Speaker, and for the information of my constituents.

March 11, 1992
The Budget
The government chose to kill off some key agencies like the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for Peace and Security.
All those organizations and commissions that had generated national discussion, invited independent thought, gave different perspectives than that which came forth from the government, gave helpful ideas and helpful opinions from top researchers and top thinkers in this world and not only in Canada.
The ideas that came forward, the research that was embarked upon perhaps at times seemed to sting and to bite the government. Perhaps it felt that the hand that was feeding it got bitten too often.
Therefore, the government decided it did not like the advice it was getting. It did not like the direction in which these organizations and councils were heading. So it decided to silence the voices of dissent and took a very dangerous step in cutting out those particular councils and commissions. I would suggest that that was a very dangerous thing for the government to have undertaken.
One of the other things that was cancelled was that of the charter challenge program. Cutting out the charter challenge program is fundamentally showing lack of respect for the poorest and the most vulnerable in our society.
That charter challenge program was to ensure that we would build a body of information of jurisprudence that would enable us to have a base from which we could judge the equality of individuals, and fairness and equity in our society. To cut out the charter challenge program is an extraordinarily cynical move.
Tb prove that the cynicism was well-founded in the budget documents, we also found it passing strange to note that this government decided to renege on its obligation as directed by a court decision and is refusing to pay the $1 billion which it owes its female employees, its own employees. I would like to know what organization or what business could get away with not paying its own employees.
The government seems to feel very comfortable. Most of those workers were women. In fact, all of them were women because it was a charter case, and the government is refusing to pay them half of the salary that they
deserve. Because it did not like where it came from, it closed down the dissent. It closed down the charter challenge fund. I would say that it just indicates the kind of thinking that went into this budget.
I was curious to know how the government was planning to look after the people of this country. I indicated all the things that the government has cut and many of the things that it did not put into place, the adjustment programs which were supposed to be put into place for free trade.
We know that the free trade agreement, because of its poor negotiations, because of its bad application, has had serious negative effects on Honda, on many major sectors like magnesium and softwood lumber.
Quebec is suffering greatly under these particular challenges as is British Columbia and other parts of this country.
We need for these workforces that are being challenged and for the thousands of manufacturing jobs and the thousands of bankruptcies that have taken place- just look at the clothing industry, look at the clothing stores across this land. We need to have some kind of retraining program, some innovative programs.
I remember in my riding when the Conservatives were running against me they kept talking about the incubator programs that they were going to put in. I said: "Good, do it. I don't care. Just do something to help the people in my riding". I have so many thousands of people in my riding who are on welfare, who are on unemployment insurance. If this government were to do something that would help them, I would be the first to compliment it.
Did the government do that? No. It did not reduce the GST. It let interest rates go up one point which over the course of a year will cost about $1.8 billion in added debt costs instead of targeting-I think I am right. I have my gurus over here and they will correct me if I am wrong.
The government could have taken that $1.8 billion that will add to the debt and if it felt comfortable in doing that by raising the interest rates, why did it not use that money in a more creative way?
Why could it not have used it for social housing and co-op housing? In my riding social housing and co-op housing have been responsible for incredible changes.
March 11, 1992

Yet I have some of the oldest housing stock in the city of Montreal and it is in serious need of repair.
There are low income people. The black community tells me it has close to 45 per cent unemployment in the category of young people between the ages of 18 and 24. The multicultural community and the other visible minorities tell me they have an unemployment rate of close to 27 per cent.
I know, and the members of this House know and I do not like to say the Maslow's hierarchy of needs, but the primary needs of a family are decent housing and decent food as bottom line minimums and we are not responding to them. When we cut out social housing and co-op housing, we are cutting out one of the fundamentals in needs.
So the co-op got chopped, social housing got cut and we still have 360,000 housing units needed in Quebec. In my riding, I want co-op housing to fix up the apartment buildings and make them usable for people today.
I talk to you about unemployment which is staggering. I talk to you about the fact that because there is this recession and because many of the unemployed in my riding are visible minorities who suffer from discrimination-unfortunately, we have not evolved enough to see people with their ability and their competence, not the colour of their skin or their disability-these people need help and this budget does nothing.
This budget is a masterpiece of workmanship done by creative bookkeepers and program packagers. But if you take a look at what is inside that box, as pretty as the design might be, there is nothing of quality, there is nothing of any value that can be used in today's society.
In this House the government has talked about the new child benefits program. I am sorry I have only two minutes left, I could go on now for hours. Gee whiz.
This new child program-I cannot believe this minister decided to say, and he stood up here and he said it and then he tried to apologize for his language. I remember his language around deranger, now I remember his language about killing VIA Rail and now he is killing child care. Let me tell you that a building block to become integrated and fully acceptable on a footing of equality in this society is a family and particularly for women is proper national child care.
The Budget
Now, the government chose not to do that just to increase the interest rates. Then it has the gall to put forward a child benefit package. It rolled together family allowance and the refundable child tax credit and it said to everybody that it was going to give them something that is great, something that is new.
The government is going to deliver a new program to their door. They are going to get a cheque that they are going to love. Sure it is the same $1,020 dollars it was before, divided into 12 parts.
But the one thing that this government did not mention is a little nasty undertaking it has put into every social program, into every tax benefit program.
Ask the seniors who know what I am talking about when they got a 75 cent increase on their cheques last month. Ask them how much that purchased for them. It is called deindexation over 3 per cent. It is called a deindexation bug that this government has put into everything that is worth while which indicates that it really does not care for the kinds of social programs that we need in this society.
If we want a decent society, we need to balance the economic with the social and I would add the cultural, because in the sense of the dynamics in which we are living, the cultural is as political as the politics in the whole question of the Constitution.
I find this budget very disturbing. I find it full of trickery and flim flam. I would like to say that with the smoke and mirrors used now, do not worry, the Liberals are coming in and we will change things, I promise you that. Poor people will be the target for us too, better than the government is doing.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank my colleague for Mount Royal for her summary of all of the deficiencies of this budget, especially the charter challenge program.
In my riding I have heard so many complaints and concerns from legitimate groups and organizations that are concerned about this particular aspect of the budget that was cut out. I thank her for bringing this to the nation's attention.
My question has to do with her area of responsibility in the national Liberal Party of Canada and that is culture and communications. Everyone in this House would

March 11, 1992
The Budget
agree that she has done a fantastic job in supporting that vital sector of our economy.
It seems to me that this government tends to want to diminish the federal presence in this country. It tends to want to shove off responsibility. In its cutting it is not only eliminating things but it is also pushing responsibility on to the provinces.
I want to ask my colleague, does she not think that this diminished Canadian presence by not really supporting arts and culture in this budget that we have lost one of the most vital instruments this country has ever had in galvanizing us as a nation?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
I thank you for your warm comments. Yes, I would like to make a comment. I was planning to do the speech on the estimates in this light.
I tried to indicate that the constitutional perturbations that we are going through right now are as much cultural as they are political.
When I read the budget report I realized that there was a $55 million cut in one area, another $35 million cut in another area, and a third $21.5 million cut. These are all in the cultural field. The government seems to have something stuck in its head about 3 per cent. The cuts in each one of the agencies adds up to a total of over $6.5 million annually over five years, which is about another $35 million. It is even more than that actually.
The interesting thing is that this government does not seem to appreciate that many of the institutions which our government put into place and promoted were in the interests of developing the artistic expression in all fields of expression.
It is the individual artist, through his freedom of expression, through his creative and intellectual thought who enriches the whole population. Individually a collective is formed which then becomes this highly diversified and unique heterogeneous multicultural society that is Canada and that is so enriched by all these talents being added in.
The government does not seem to feel that is a good idea. It put forward policies that do absolutely nothing to enrich this country in that regard. Just have a look at the film policy it put in that was terrible and that did not go through. The book publishing policy of which it is very proud ended up being a 10 cent on the dollar investment.
I would say that the indications all along the way are although it wishes to maintain the national institutions and although there is definitely a recognition on everyone's part that culture is not just the high arts, it is everyday living and everything else, from the couch potato through to whatever else one wants to do-go to the hockey game. There is a role for the municipalities, there is a role for the provinces and there is a role for the federal government. The over-arching goal of the federal government is to enable us to know, understand and appreciate each other from coast to coast to coast. The role of the provinces is to enable the institutions and organisms that are within that province to flourish and grow, particularly museums, libraries, local arts festivals and things of that nature. Artists, by the very nature of their independence must, should and shall maintain the right to knock on every door, federal, provincial, municipal and private sector.
I hope that in a sense I have answered the question. I can only say that the $2.6 billion that we spend on arts and culture in this country, which includes the CBC, is certainly not enough. We must improve in that area. Allan Gotlieb told us that we need $47 million as a beginner in Canada Council alone if we want to do anything. What does the government do? It cuts the Canada Council I think by $260 million.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is an honour to be able to participate in this budget debate and to share this time slot with my hon. friend from Sarnia.
I would like to address this budget from the perspective of someone representing an agricultural riding in the west. I want to especially stress the concerns of people in that area, not just as they relate to agriculture but to the economy generally, their concern about the family, about fairness and taxation, wanting to see a reduction in the duplication and waste in government agencies.
At the outset it has been suggested by some in opposition that this budget does nothing for agriculture. Of course that is a complete falsehood. Not only do we have support for agriculture in terms of policies leading to lower interest rates-these not just for agriculture but for all Canadians-but we have a revised child tax benefit which is targeted to those who need it. We have a continuation of agricultural policies which we are deliv-
March 11, 1992

ering to the grains and oilseed sector this year, something in the order of $4 billion.
It is true that in the minds of some and indeed for some producers that is not enough to sustain them. In the minds of many taxpayers it is far too much. The problem lies beyond our borders. We all know that the difficulties in agriculture are caused by this disastrous trade war that has been going on between the United States and the European Community. That problem lies beyond our borders and indeed in many ways the solution will be found there as well through multilateral negotiation, hopefully through a GATT deal.
Another concern for people in my area of Swift Current-Maple Creek-Assiniboia is western diversification. Part and parcel of the concern that we have with agriculture, with our over-dependence on the export of grain, is the search for other things to do for diversification in an area which basically lends itself very much to the growing of grain for export.
In that regard we have the continuing support of the Department of Western Economic Diversification which is a $1.2 billion revolving fund that was established some years ago by this government with the express view of trying to stimulate, as it names implies, diversification in the west so that loans are made to individual and corporate entrepreneurs for new market, new product, new technology, import replacement, innovation and job creation. That program, I am happy to say, has been extremely successful in my area and many people continue to be enormously supportive of it. So support continues for agriculture and it continues for diversification.
Having said that, I want to touch on some of the highlights of this budget document as I believe people in my constituency see them. First and foremost is the taxation of families. There is an element of fairness in this because finally married couples are going to be treated the same way as those who choose to live common law. Unfortunately over the years a number of elements have entered into the taxation system which have combined to place a much greater tax burden on married couples compared to those who choose to live together. I point to the GST credit, the child tax credit, principal residence, attribution rules, the equivalent to married exemption and so on.
The Budget
As was pointed out by a number of my colleagues in the Conservative caucus, I want to pay tribute to my colleague, the member for Calgary North, for chairing that caucus which has brought forward a number of very useful suggestions.
Based on those recommendations, we do have these measures in the budget which I think will find considerable favour, not just in my constituency but across the country. Why should there be a bias away from the traditional married couple?
The second element in the taxation of families which I think is extremely important is the child care deduction. The maximum available has been increased. I will not go into the details of it, as it is contained within those documents.
The third area is the enriching of benefits for families with children. In that regard, we have a major reform of the existing system in that one monthly child tax benefit will replace the current patchwork of assistance. The family allowance, the child tax credit and the refundable child credit will be amalgamated and the single monthly payment will make the system simpler and more responsive to family needs by targeting more fairly the low and middle income families.
Child benefits will increase by $400 million a year in a cumulative way. There will be a maximum of $144 a month per child for low and middle income families and a new earned income supplement of up to $500 for the working poor as well as the increases in child care deductions which I referred to earlier.
I believe this will find favour with my constituents who have questioned for a number of years the point of continuing to pay family allowances to well-off Canadians. They will applaud the idea of taking these moneys and instead targeting them for those who are most in need.
Other areas that my constituents have indicated concern about and which I believe this budget addresses are the streamlining of government and expenditure restraint. In regard to the streamlining of government, I am happy to point out that in this budget there will be eliminated, consolidated or deferred about 46 government agencies, many of which have been referred to in this debate and contained in the documents. They are agencies such as the Petroleum Monitoring Agency, the Pay Research Bureau, the Law Reform Commission, Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada and so on. As well, there will be a consolidation of a number of departments

March 11, 1992
The Budget
and agencies in order to save overhead and to focus resources.
I have just one example. Right now, there is the Patent Appeal Board, the Trade Marks Opposition Board and the Copyright Board. These will be merged into a new intellectual property tribunal. A number of advisory councils are going to be terminated. There will be 160 fewer government appointments, 500 fewer employees and savings of $22 million a year.
The government is going to continue to privatize those Crown corporations which are not serving an essential public purpose. It is going to sell surplus land at various places and properties abroad that are no longer needed. I believe these are initiatives which reflect the wishes of Canadians as expressed to members of Parliament.
In regard to the restraint of expenditures, the Expenditure Control Plan which was announced in the budget in 1990 and enlarged last year will be carried forward. As a result of the defence review and taking into account the conditions, the startling events, especially in the former Soviet Union and eastern Europe, we will be able to reduce the commitment to the armed forces and defence spending will be cut by over $2 billion over the next five years.
As well, the non-wage operating budgets of government departments will be cut by 3 per cent which will save $150 million next year and $800 million over a five-year period. This is on top of the wage restraint measures which are well known to Canadians. All in all, these are measures which answer the public need.
As well, listed in the budget are a number of actions for investment initiatives and jobs. The manufacturing and processing sectors have been hard hit. A fifth of the Canadian economy and jobs depend on this area. As a result of globalization, as a result of intensive international competition and world-wide recession there have been difficulties. The world economy is profoundly changing. The barriers to movement of goods, services, capital and information are coming down everywhere. Industry all around the world is restructuring to take
advantage of new opportunities. The Canadian work place, like others elsewhere, is being transformed.
Mr. Speaker, I realize the time restraints. I simply want to point out that the manufacturing and processing sector is one which is in intense competition with the rest of the world. We owe it to that sector to modestly reduce the income tax rate applying to it from 23 per cent to 21 per cent, to increase the rate of depreciation on processing and manufacturing equipment from 25 per cent to 30 per cent. This will put the manufacturing and processing sectors of Canada in a better position to compete, along with the imposition of the GST, which will relieve those sectors of the unfair burden of paying sales tax input costs.
These measures together will help to ensure the competitiveness of our manufacturing and processing sectors compared to those in other nations which have similar tax regimes.
I believe this is a very realistic budget for the times. It is, I think, an answer to the requests of Canadians who want to see restraint on the part of government, who do not want to see new taxes and who want to see moneys that are put out universally, targeted instead toward those who most need them.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to stand in the House and speak today on the budget. I am very pleased to have this opportunity because the budget can have a very special and positive impact on the business opportunities that could come to my riding.
I want to applaud the Minister of Finance on the measures he announced in this budget. As has been noted by most everyone throughout this country, it is veiy positive. The general tone and direction that it takes is right. It proposes realistic, long-lasting solutions to our country's economic problems. It does not propose quick fixes, which is something that is very important to Canadians, and they have responded positively to that. It also represents a commitment by our government to adjust to the same economic realities which Canadian
March 11, 1992

households and businesses face each day. That is why so many people can relate to this budget.
Of course it means belt tightening, responsible management, not simply carefree, wanton spending. It responds to the desire to have a more expansive economy and a less expensive and more efficient government. We must constantly and continually work to that end.
Canadians across the land are telling us that they want a more efficient government. They want a less expensive government and they want an expansive economy that has some long-term structure to it.
In my mind the budget delivers on a number of fronts. It delivers on what Canadians have told us in our consultations across the country, including the residents of my riding. I have received letters from organizations and people in my riding of Sarnia-Lamb ton thanking me for taking their thoughts forward because their suggestions ended up in the budget.
The equation to help boost our economic recovery is really simple in this budget. The federal government is cutting spending to cut taxes. I think it was a real surprise to the opposition that we were cutting taxes. Sometimes they have a little bit of trouble responding to that but it is what Canadians are looking for and certainly we have given them a very strong message that we are doing that.
Local residents are concerned also about the spending and the size of government, as I said, and we are responding to that.
The budget outlines measures to restructure, to streamline and to improve the operations of government. The budget proposes to cut spending, just the opposite of what really has gone on in the past. It will be cut by $1 billion this year and by over $7 billion in the next five years. It is very important to Canadians to see that. It seems to me it is quite the opposite in some of the submissions I have heard from across the way today. They are saying that we should be spending more money on this or we should be spending more money on that. That is not what Canadians are saying.
Thrning to defence spending, we are going to take advantage of the peace dividend for Canada. There will be a substantial peace dividend for all of us and we will
The Budget
be able to cut the spending in defence. That is very important.
Residents in my riding like all Canadians are concerned about taxes. They do not want to pay more taxes. They are concerned about the taxes that they are paying and they understand that that comes from this increased and ever-increasing spending of government.
As I noted earlier, personal income taxes will be cut. Over 14 million individual taxpayers will enjoy higher disposable income as a result of this budget. Having higher income means there is more disposable dollars. Those disposable dollars help the economy because people have to buy if we are going to stimulate manufacturing. These reductions will put $500 million back into the hands of the taxpayers this coming fiscal year. That is very important. The total benefit will increase to almost $1.2 billion in subsequent years. That kind of injection of money back into the economy certainly will help.
My constituents looked also for a cut in the deficit. The government has made a commitment to address the deficit. Despite the economic slowdown, the government had held the deficit and will reduce it by up to $4 billion this coming year. Certainly we are moving on the right track. Canadians are saying they want this done, and we are responding.
I am particularly encouraged by the assistance to the local petrochemical and refining industry which is certainly a very important industry in my area of Sarnia- Lambton. It is a major industry there. It is a very capital intensive industry. It costs a lot of money to build those plants.
In this budget the federal government has moved to reduce the tax burden for the manufacturing and processing sectors which will include the petrochemical and refining industry. The budget proposes these important changes. The basic corporate income tax on manufacturing and processing will be reduced from 23 per cent to 22 per cent on January 1,1993. It will also go down to 21 per cent on January 1, 1994.
There is another very important one, the capital cost allowance rate. That is the opportunity for companies to write off this major investment that they make, especially in the petrochemical industry. To build a world scale petrochemical plant today costs up to three-quarters of a billion dollars and takes up to two years. Certainly they

March 11, 1992
The Budget
have a very heavy capital investment and they want to be able to have the capital cost allowance. They did want it changed.
I had representation made to me by constituents who represent the companies in my area. They said to me: "If we are going to have new world scale plants built in the Sarnia-Lambton area to produce world scale production for North America then the after tax situation needs to be changed. We would like to see some change in the capital cost allowance".
I want to let my constituents know, and also you, Mr. Speaker, and my colleagues in this House, that I took their representations. I took representations from Canadian chemical producers and I made my representation to the Minister of Finance. I indicated that this was the kind of change we needed to attract investment, to have the write-off. I indicated that the capital cost allowance had to be changed to a higher rate. The Minister of Finance listened and responded by including this in the budget. I want to thank him for listening and responding. That is as tremendously important as it is for a lot of other areas too, but especially in the high capital intensive industries like we have in Sarnia-Lambton.
Additionally a couple of other important areas were added to help with the building of new world scale plants in my area. There is a reduction in the tax rate that will help us, but also we have the reduction of the withholding tax rate on direct dividends to 5 per cent. This will also encourage investment.
A day or so before the budget was announced the government was to reverse the order of the credit currently provided for large corporations tax especially in part VI, the tax on financial institutions, the corporate surtax and income tax. That is another complicated tax. Those four areas will mean substantive changes to after tax situations for investments by multinationals in the petrochemical and refining industry.
We also need the provincial government to assist us in this area. We are saying that we have made these substantive changes. We are asking the province of Ontario not to move into that tax room. We are also saying: "Hey, you come on board and give us a hand.
Make some changes now in the after tax situation". I think Premier Rae is hopefully interested in working for this. Then Sarnia-Lambton and other areas-of course I am particularly interested in Sarnia-Lambton-will attract new world scale petrochemical plants to be built there. There is a major plant in the offering and we are competing with Texas for this plant.
A combination of the kinds of changes we have made and the after tax changes that hopefully the province of Ontario can make will provide with us a greater opportunity to have investment, which means a world scale plant, which means jobs in Sarnia-Lambton, jobs for Canadians.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I certainly wanted the debate to go forward until I heard the member suggest that Bob Rae should lend the government a hand when in fact the federal government slaps the provincial government. The member would know that over the course of three years the transfer payments will be reduced by $10 billion. How does he anticipate lending a helping hand when that kind of reaction from the federal government to the provincial government is in place and has been in place with the cap on CAP and the cap on transfer payments?
He would know because I am sure it is happening in his riding as well as mine that hospital beds and hospitals services are being reduced. Teaching staffs are being hit right across the board. How can he possibly suggest that the provincial government should lend a hand to the federal government when the federal government is battering provincial governments?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very surprised by that statement. I do not think Premier Rae is reacting in that manner. Certainly my provincial colleague in Sarnia who is a member of the NDP is not. We are acting as a partnership in moving ahead to do the kinds of things to attract investment. The member may want to be partisan, but my colleague and partner, the MPP for Sarnia, is not reacting in that way. He is working very hard, as I think the province of Ontario will be, not to change and move into the tax room but to look at ways they can be helpful in working with the federal government to attract the major kind of build we are talking about in Sarnia. They are some very major builds that will provide jobs.
March 11, 1992

The province of Ontario is as interested as the federal government in providing jobs. I would think the member, though I suppose late in the day, might want to get into some partisan rhetoric. Knowing him personally I am surprised at that statement. He can make it, but I do not think he is speaking for the Government of Ontario because I would think that its thinking is somewhat different from that.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today I welcome the opportunity to speak on the budget introduced by the Minister of Finance in this Chamber on February 25, some 15 days ago.
We have now had ample time to review, to analyse and to discuss the provisions in that budget and what it means to us and to our constituencies.
I have heard during the debate in this House and in conversations I have had in my constituency that the response to the budget is not very good. The message from northwest Saskatchewan which I represent is very simple and I can relate it very quickly to members of this House.
The government must be aware that regional resource based economies like ours in Saskatchewan require greater attention than that which it is receiving at this time. The problems in the national economy have a greater impact on the west and therefore the root causes of the national problems, that is the GST and the free trade agreement, must be addressed and they have not been addressed in this budget.
If we scrap the GST and get out of the FTA we will all be better off. That is a message that comes from my constituents in The Battlefords-Meadow Lake. I have to mention that the government opposite had better prepare for greater agricultural support during 1992-93. I am glad that the Minister of Agriculture has indicated to me his desire to listen to my words today.
As I have already said in this House, this budget does not address the financial problems faced by agricultural producers on the prairies. The uncertainties that exist in the countryside and in the world marketplace will lead to further calls for agricultural assistance during 1992. The government is foolish to think that it can avoid programs like the interest-free cash advance and deficiency assistance programs this year.
The Budget
Earlier this week, in fact on Monday, I made a brief statement in the House of Commons concerning one small provision in the budget, that is the provision relating to the removal of the excise tax on the ethanol portion of blended fuels. I want to take half a minute to expand on the comments I made on Monday, elaborate a little on the statement I made, and indicate my support to the Minister of Agriculture and others on the government side for the moves that have been made on ethanol.
I want to do this because I am quite impressed with what I see as the future for ethanol in Canada. It is a future that can help provide for a cleaner environment and greater economic benefits for smaller, rural based communities like those that make up my constituency.
After the introduction of the budget I had great pleasure to tour the Poundmaker ethanol plant and feed lot at Lanigan, Saskatchewan with a group of people from Big River and Debden, Saskatchewan, two communities in my constituency. During that tour we learned a lot and recognized that with the right economic climate similar plants could be located in numerous communities in Saskatchewan and across Canada.
The advantages are almost too numerous to mention but in a moment I will try to outline a number. Ethanol is not a new product. It has a number of useful purposes, but what we are most interested in at this time is its use as an automotive fuel enhancer.
Some members in the House today may recall that when Henry Ford designed the Model T he had expected it to be powered by ethanol, a fuel made from renewable biological materials. However gasoline powered engines took over and ethanol has been an industry trying to get off the ground ever since. Its time has come and I think it is time we all recognize that Canada would be well advised to get into the act of producing ethanol immediately or risk losing the opportunities to the Americans.
Already dozens of ethanol producing plants have sprung up in the United States. Some state legislatures have even passed bills making ethanol blended fuels mandatory. As a result ethanol blended gasoline now accounts for about 9 per cent of total U.S. gas consumption.

The Budget
The use of ethanol blended gasoline fuel has been actively encouraged in the United States because it helps to reduce U.S. dependence on oil imports, that is a 10 per cent blend acts as a gas extender. Ten per cent ethanol means that there is 10 per cent fuel oil left over for use elsewhere. It addresses a number of environmental concerns including, first, emissions and, second, it lessens the environmental hazards of fossil fuel exploration, extraction and transportation. Also, the U.S. is actively encouraging ethanol production because it provides a market opportunity for surplus agricultural crops.
The Poundmaker plant that I visited, for example, uses a starch heavy, not protein heavy, grain as its stock, while other plants in Canada will use corn instead of wheat for its feedstocks.
The value of ethanol as a fuel increases every day because of the world's concern for the environment, the health of this planet, its people and its wildlife, and the need to seek alternatives to the megaproject mentality that has limited job opportunities for people in this country for too long. This means there are sound economics as well as sound environmental reasons to get into ethanol production. As I see it, there could be six basic economic reasons to support a change to ethanol.
First, the high octane-blending value of ethanol makes it an excellent replacement for the octane enhancers with known or suspected health concerns, now widely used in Canadian gasoline following the removal of tetra-ethyl lead by legislation here in Canada. Ethanol can substitute for aromatic hydrocarbons, which includes MMT, a compound containing manganese which, like lead, is a potential neurotoxin and accumulates over time in the environment. MMT already is banned in the United States.
Second, the Government of Canada projects that by the mid-1990s Canada will be importing about 550,000 barrels of light crude oil per day by tankers to meet transportation fuel needs. This is even with the added supply to be created by the new megaproject developments. This importation will cost about $5.5 billion a year, assuming a global crude oil price of about $27 a barrel due to increasing dependence on OPEC imports.
Third, the cost, financial and environmental, of megaprojects is too great for enhancing Canadian domestic supplies of light crude oil. Fuel ethanol compares favourably, in both capital and operating costs of production, to Hibernia and the tar sands projects, which can only proceed with a lot of government assistance.
Fourth, the abundant supply of Canadian grain is available for fuel ethanol production and is renewable, endlessly renewable.
Fifth, the by-product of ethanol production from grain, which is a high-protein livestock feed ingredient, could be used to replace Canadian imports of high-protein feeds.
Sixth, and last, the effect of ethanol additions to gasoline on environmental quality is incredible. Its potential to reduce net carbon dioxide emissions into the atmosphere is considerable.
There is great concern about global warming in the country. Among the greatest contributors to the problem of the greenhouse effect is the burning of fossil fuels. By adding ethanol to those fossil fuels burned in automobiles, the amount of carbon released into the atmosphere is reduced substantially.
I am a member of the environment committee's subcommittee on acid rain. Because we are looking at air qualities and emission problems, I will be recommending that our committee take a look at ethanol production and its use during its work over the coming year.
I know you are signalling me that my time is almost up. I want to add in closing that the budget's removal of the excise tax is a step in the right direction but the journey is far from complete. There has to be a further federal commitment to the ethanol industry, and that includes a commitment to promote the product as well as to legislate in the product development.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the obvious question to the member is simply this: After listening to him, I have come to the realization that he does not have a whole lot of criticism of the budget introduced February 25. Is the member willing to support our budget based on his observations, particularly in his own riding? Obviously there are some positives in this budget for his riding, his part of the country. That is the question.
March 11, 1992

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in order to address the budget adequately, I need about an hour and a half of the House's time to discuss all of the things that I find wrong with the budget.
What is very important to me are the two lines the government put in an otherwise very long and difficult budget. Two lines indicate a desire to move in the right direction as far as energy and the environment is concerned and relating to the production of ethanol.
If I can take one moment of the House's time to add that I do believe that the government should be actively involved in the legislative process regarding ethanol. A mandatory 10 per cent blend is part of a legislative process in the United States. I believe this government must take the same steps here in Canada. In fact, we should see the government legislating mandatory blends for Canadian ethanol production here in Canada. We would see the potential of creating up to 3 billion litres a year of ethanol if we were to ask for 10 per cent of the 30 billion litres of fuel oil consumed in this country per year.
I will be actively asking the government to consider moves in this direction.
The government's budgetary moves were a signal to the industry that the government wants to take steps in this direction, a signal to the industry and the country that ethanol is a product that should be supported. I want the government to understand that if it takes steps to assist the communities involved in ethanol development, and the industry itself, it will have support from this comer.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would also like to ask the member a question in light of the very positive comments he made about the benefit to his riding of this tax or of this budget and the clear benefits that will occur to many of the members from Ontario who are part of his party that represent automotive ridings.
There is a reduction in the income tax for automotive companies, a reduction in the capital gains or capital cost allowances, the reduction in the dividend withholding tax, all of which are very good employment creation ideas for NDP-held ridings in Ontario. I wonder if in light of the fact that it is good for his riding in Western Canada and in Saskatchewan and it is good for all his colleagues' ridings in Ontario if he is now going to rise
The Budget
when the occasion happens to vote on the budget to support the budget as he should, based on all of the good things that are in it?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I cannot give the hon. member the answer which he so desperately wants to hear.
I am signalling support for a small measure within the budget that I otherwise find distasteful and most difficult for us to accept. I indicated there will have to be measures taken like the interest free cash advance again this year for farm producers in Saskatchewan and elsewhere. I have indicated in my response on this ethanol matter that community-based assistance is the type of economic development assistance that the government must be involved in. When producers on the prairies or in Ontario get together to form co-operatives to develop ethanol plants, the government should be there to help them with the start-up costs to ensure that the benefits from such production come back to the communities and support community employment activities.
These are the kinds of things the government should be moving on to further the development it has started in those couple of lines in this budget.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all, I want to congratulate my colleague for the excellent lesson on ethanol.
Obviously he has a tremendous amount of expertise that he wants to share with the members opposite. I think his philosophy is that if you have nothing positive to say about something do not say it.
I would like to follow his philosophy but I did have a few negatives written down so I may have to be slightly negative as my time wears on. I do want to start by being positive. I am going to quote several excerpts from a speech given about a month before the budget came out. I must admit that I am going to quote out of context.
"We must have a short-term plan to address our immediate needs and heat up the economy. We need a long-term plan to keep the combustion going and to guarantee our place in the world economy". Skip a paragraph. "Further, for the untold number of hardworking, responsible workers and businessmen and women who have been forced to go without needed bank loans-" I will talk about banks later on- "the banking

March 11, 1992
The Budget
credit crunch must end. I have directed cabinet departments and federal agencies to speed up pro-growth expenditures as quickly as possible. This should put an extra $10 million into the economy in the next six.months and our transportation bill provides more than $150 million for construction and maintenance projects that are vital to our growth and well-being. That means jobs building roads, jobs building bridges and jobs building railways. I said my plan has two parts and it does, and the second part is the heart of the matter for it is not enough to get an immediate burst. We need long-term improvement in our economic position".
These are excerpts from a speech made by President Bush. I only wish that the Prime Minister and the finance minister had used some of the content from the President's speech as they so often do. They are wont to follow the President on a very regular basis. This is one time they did not and perhaps they should have.
To continue in a positive way. This is not a bad budget. It is not a bad budget in good times, but these are bad times, terrible times. The "R" word is almost a "D" word. It is a budget that has a little bit of something for just about everybody. I call it a tinkering budget. You tinker here with the system, help somebody over here and take away over here. However, the system and the country need an overhaul. There are 1.5 million people unemployed, personal and business bankruptcies are at record levels, welfare case loads were up 32 per cent in Ontario in January 1992 compared to 1991, 32 per cent. The number of individuals collecting UI in November 1991 was 486,000, up 23 per cent over November 1990. The number of individuals who have exhausted their UI is 32,500-this is just in Ontario-up 111 per cent over November of the previous year. One and three-quarter million people ate at food banks in this country in one year.
How could one continue to be positive? I salute the member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake. He avoided the budget because it was so difficult to proceed in anything positive. What will this budget do for those people I have cited? Absolutely nothing. The transfer payments from the federal government to the province of Ontario, one of the so-called have provinces, the cap on CAP and the EPF transfer payments will result in a $10.5 billion reduction over three years.
It is a pass the buck budget but there are no bucks being passed. There was nothing passed to the provinces. What do the provinces have to do? They cannot pass the buck to the municipalities. The finance minister has the gall to lecture Premier Rae saying: "I hope he follows our path". What does he suggest we do? Close the hospitals completely, cut out the education system? He is saying: "We are practising restraint and we want you to follow our lead". Does he want to practise what John Engler has done in Michigan? He basically cut the welfare system and said: "People get out on the streets. Live in tents. It is not a problem".
Even one of those folks who is a supporter of John Engler, the governor of Michigan, says: "Well, pulling the safety net probably will not be a money saver". He pulls out a study from a brief case and throws it on the table. He points out research that says: "Five per cent of those cut off welfare, if they end up in prison and another 5 per cent end up in mental institutions, the state will pay out more than it saves in welfare payments". In fact, says Hollister, an aide of John Engler, in a steady voice: "Cutting people off welfare was not an economic decision, it was an ideological decision. It was an abandonment of the social contract". Because the federal government abandons the social contract it then says to the premier of Ontario: "Do the same thing. It does not matter about these people, allow them to live in tents. Cut back medical services in your community".
I am sure that all of our communities are suffering those medical cutbacks. Staff is being cut in hospitals and schools right across the country. Is that acceptable? I think not. That is what Canadians in my constituency are telling me. The Prime Minister and the finance minister have passed that buck but they have not passed the money. They have soured federal-provincial relations, federal-Ontario relations when they should not be doing so. They should be begging to co-operate. The government should be promoting a spirit of co-operation rather than saying: "Follow our lead, look what we have done, look at the wondrous things we have done".
I suspect that the provincial government will not follow the federal government. The federal government is crossing this country as it is wont to do every month or so with a prosperity agenda. The committee came to my city, and I believe there were 12 people there. It described how to become more competitive: "You know, all we have to do is retrain our people. We have to retrain them. That will make us more competitive". What did the government do in the budget? It said that
March 11, 1992

we have to reduce job training by $100 million. Now that will make us more competitive. It should have taken a positive step because nearly everyone in this country- and if its members are indeed consulting those in their constituency the government would have invested in the infrastructure of this country.
Several years ago the price tag was $15 billion. It is now $20 billion. I hope we do become prosperous again-and I suspect we will. I long for those days and I am sure all Canadians long for those days. If we do not have the infrastructure to support a prosperous economic situation-will our infrastructure be able to support it? Is it possible? A hundred and some communities are still pouring raw sewage into the waterways of this country, is that acceptable? If we did not do it in good times we are not going to do it in bad times. When are we going to do it? There was a great belief that this was the time to do it, everybody was onside and prepared to participate. The only non-participant was the federal government.
This budget is a maze. I think it is too positive to say that it is smoke and mirrors. It is a maze that leads from one spot to another. On one hand the government will do something for you and on the other hand it will take it away. It has increased the education tuition credit for students and parents from $60 to $80 a month and in the same breath it removed the 60-day grace period to pay back student loans which existed prior to the budget. Give with one hand, take with another.
Disability credits have been increased for those who are disabled in this country. Give with that hand. With the other hand cut out co-op housing to house disabled people. The family allowance has been removed. The government says: "We are going to increase your child tax credit". If you work it out, and it has been worked out by Mr. Shiffrin, The Toronto Star social affairs writer, the amount that is given will amount to the very same amount. Those most in need of it will get less. It is the working poor who will be helped and we praise that, but again it is an attack on universality.
I want to speak for the last 30 seconds on banks. The government has done something for small business, that
The Budget
is again a positive. However the banks in this country have a tight money policy. George Bush says they have it in the United States but the banks in Canada make the banks in the United States appear like Mary Poppins. They are squeezing the small businesses in this country.
If any member goes out in their constituency and asks, that is exactly what small businesses will tell you. Banks are not only squeezing, the small businesses say: "I will not talk to my banker because I am afraid". The budget is terrible. I rest my case.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a very short question to ask the member.
Will he not agree with me that this government is going across the globe spendthrifting? It is going across the globe saying to everybody: "We will give you this, we will give you that". The Prime Minister is acting like he is a wondrous human being. He went to Paris and he let them have a drawing for $1 million. Will the member not agree with me that charity starts at home and this is where we should look after our children, today and not tomorrow?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it may have begun as a simple question but the answer could be very complex. I think that all of us in here believe that charity does begin at home, but we cannot ignore charity overseas.
For instance, if the banks forgive loans to Third World countries we can be assured that they have already received the principal on those loans. They may be forgiving the interest. Do not worry, the banks have gotten their share. Also, they are able to sell off this Third World debt.
I suspect I could go on for a long time with that answer. It started out simple but the answer is complex.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wanted to comment on the member's reaction to the transfers to the provinces.
I would like to debate that point and that point only in relation to the figures. He represents one of the richest provinces in Canada, that being Ontario. I want to

March 11, 1992
The Budget
examine the figures in the last number of years of the transfers from the Government of Canada to the province of Ontario.
It is interesting to note that the average annual increase from 1984-85 to 1992-93 in growth of those transfer dollars to Ontario has been an annualized one of 6.2 per cent. We are looking at a total increase from 1984-85 to 1992-93 of $3.7 billion.
On a per capita basis it is a transfer of approximately $283.1 cannot see the logic in his argument. I know he is projecting ahead to what they might or might not get, but those are merely projections. The truth is that we are going to continue to increase our support to the provinces.
I hope the member will address that.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would be happy to address the problem.
I think the member is, as we all do, using statistics to his own advantage. I suspect I may be guilty of that at times too. However he has to get real. Everyone keeps saying that Ontario is a wealthy province.
Any members from Ontario will tell you just the opposite. Sault Ste. Marie is one community that is desperately hard hit. He throws statistics at me but the number of people who have exhausted their UI in the past year, just over the past 12 months, is up 110 per cent. That is a staggering statistic.
He throws these global figures at me and asks: "How do you react to these hundreds of millions of dollars in increases?" That may very well be true, but it does not begin to address the real problem. That is the problem with the members opposite. They are in some imaginary world saying: "We are listening to our people. Do you know what they are telling us? We are doing a great job".
That cannot possibly be true. I know the member is a very sincere individual but I think he is trying to deceive the House. I retract that, Mr. Speaker.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to convey my sympathies to the Minister of Finance on this recent budget. I can only imagine what a horrendous job it must have been trying to repair an economy that unfortunately his own government has virtually destroyed. No doubt the minister has done his best in trying to produce an effective budget. I cannot
fault him for that. But as the Canadian Chamber of Commerce has said: "The budget falls short; it is simply not good enough". The chamber could not be more correct in its analysis.
This budget attempts to be all things to all people and in so doing does nothing for anyone. In short, this budget is a non-event, there is no significant attempt to either reduce spending or stimulate the economy.
In a recent Maclean's article the Minister of Finance has said: "If the Reform Party supports the budget that is fine. I guess the important thing is that we (meaning the Conservative government) are here and we are able to implement these things".
First let me say unequivocally that the Reform Party cannot support this budget. Second, I would like to ask the minister what he means by being able to implement these things. What things? Is he talking about implementing the so-called spending cuts mentioned in the budget speech?
Are Canadians supposed to be impressed that the government has cut spending increases only, not actual spending? Canadians are looking for real reductions in government spending, not simply a reduction in the percentage increase. In fact, the government's program expenditures are forecast to rise by 4.7 per cent in fiscal 1992-93, well in excess of the 2.7 per cent inflation rate we are experiencing now. This represents a real increase in spending, not a reduction as the government would have Canadians believe.
It would be unparliamentary, of course, that I cast aspersions and say that the government, perhaps, is lying to Canadians about spending reductions. So I could not and would not say that. But how can Canadians have any confidence that this government is serious about deficit reduction when spending is actually on the rise. This government's projection for 1992-93 expenditures represents a real increase of $4.1 billion or 2.6 per cent.
The 1991-92 deficit is nearly a billion dollars higher than previously forecast and the 1992-93 deficit, now forecast at $27.5 billion, is also significantly higher than had been predicted in earlier budgets. What we have in effect is a government that every year paints a picture of declining deficits and every year fails to deliver on this promise.
March 11, 1992

How much longer can Canadians tolerate the failure of this government to actually reduce the annual deficit? Not much longer, I would argue, especially when the accumulated total debt is approaching half a trillion dollars. That is right, Mr. Speaker, half a trillion dollars, edging in on $500 billion that we are in debt. It is time for the government to take action on this economic crisis before it is too late. The government's tired excuse of "we will get the deficit down next year" simply will not cut it with Canadians any longer.
Part of the rationale for the government's deficit reduction projection is its overly optimistic economic forecast. While I have every confidence in the entrepreneurial spirit and work ethic of Canadians, I have serious reservations about the government's forecast of real GDP-GNP growth achieving 4.5 per cent, as we have seen in the budget papers for 1993.
This is a rather bold prediction and Canadians can, therefore, only hope the government is accurate in its analysis. If the government has over-estimated this GDP figure, inevitably it has also over-estimated its ability to reduce the deficit. Moreover the minister has built his budget on the foundations of a very low inflation rate. If he is wrong, if the inflation rate increases and if high interest rates follow, the foundations will give way and the whole structure will collapse.
The government expects this phenomenal growth to be led by a strong increase in residential construction and consumer spending in response to lower interest rates. But what has the government done to encourage construction and consumer spending? The short answer is very little.
Under pressure from the Liberal Party to accept its one and only idea to stimulate the economy, the minister threw in a token homebuyer's plan that would allow Canadians to use existing funds from their registered retirement savings plans to buy a principal residence. Under this plan, individuals may withdraw up to $20,000 to buy a home and would have to repay this amount within 15 years. Is this the best the government could do? Or should I say is this the best the Liberal Party could come up with to encourage growth in the economy? Perhaps it is just a bad joke.
The Budget
I do not want to condemn the government for absolutely everything that it has done. There were some positive moves in this. But one does have to answer the question, does anyone in his or her right mind think that this plan is going to pull our economy out of the recession. I cannot think of anyone who has been putting money into their RRSP in anticipation of a magnanimous gesture by the government.
It would also seem to me that anyone who has $20,000 in their RRSP fund more than likely already has a principal residence. The converse of that is true as well, that young families that want to buy a house and are prepared to do so do not have a lot of savings in their RRSP. I wonder where this great infusion of capital into the housing sector is supposed to come from.
The most disturbing element of this proposal, however, is that the government is telling people to use their retirement income to buy a home in what is already a very uncertain market. The government has already mortgaged the future of Canadians through the public debt and now it is asking them to mortgage their future privately as well through their RRSP plans.
There is absolutely no guarantee over this 15 year payback period of what interest rates will be and I think people are very nervous about taking that money which was safe in their RRSP fund out to put toward a mortgage.
Perhaps the government believes that consumer spending will increase because of an insignificant symbolic personal income tax cut. The Canadian Chamber of Commerce has concluded, and I quote: "That small personal tax reduction and the provisions to encourage business would be too small to have a meaningful impact in stimulating growth, yet large enough to call into question the real strength of the government's commitment to deficit and debt reduction."
According to the government's own figures, a single taxpayer earning $30,000 will receive a tax reduction of $76 in 1993.1 wonder if this single taxpayer is going to be terribly excited in receiving this generous tax break after having been hit by the GST last year.
What the government is effectively saying through this measure is that the GST is making them so much money that a tax reduction of such minuscule proportions will not adversely affect revenues. The government is taking a dollar from every Canadian in the form of the GST and

March 11, 1992
The Budget
then handing them back a penny saying: "Here is your tax reduction".
The government has also neglected to mention the fact that personal income taxes as a percentage of total federal spending have increased from 41.2 per cent in 1984-85 when this government took office to 47.7 per cent in 1992-93. This indicates that more and more the government has been shifting the burden of federal spending on to the backs of the middle class.
This so-called tax break is much like the government's attempt at spending reduction. These policies are designed to have Canadians believe that taxes and spending are actually being reduced but in reality both taxes and spending are actually increasing.
To be entirely fair to the government, however, as my colleagues have been saying, there are some good things in this budget for which we need to give them credit. One of the areas that I would like to give the government credit for is adopting the new child benefit. This new benefit finally targets child supplements more fairly to low and middle income families. The government must have been reading our Reform Party polity book where it states: "The Reform Party supports greater focusing of social policy benefits. We prefer to target benefits on those who need the help and do so in a rational and compassionate manner."
It is about time the government woke up to the need for this type of efficient method of providing for social benefits rather than clinging to the NDP dogma that allowed high income earners to receive family allowance cheques regardless of their need. Sometimes I wonder if the New Democrats really mean what they say about helping the poor. Why do we not target benefits to the poor rather than having those of us who are very comfortable in our income bracket still collecting government money when it is totally unnecessary?
At any rate, the government is certainly moving in the right direction with this new consolidated child benefit.
My only question is this. If this new benefit is to be streamlined and more effectively focused as the government says it is, why will it cost taxpayers an additional
$400 million per year? I thought the government said it was reducing expenditures, not increasing them.
Besides this new child benefit, the government has also attempted to appropriate other Reform Party policies in this budget and nobody says it more clearly than the press because they know what is going on and it is very interesting to read what some of their articles say. I say attempted because the government has not really done the things that it says it actually has. Ihke, for example, this budget's privatization initiative or streamlining as it is referred to in the budget speech. The government is obviously gearing up for an election so that when the time comes it can go to the Canadian public and say: "Oh look, the Reform Party has nothing on us. In this last budget, we wound up, deferred, merged and privatized 46 government agencies, boards, commissions, corporations and advisory boards."
This all sounds very good on the surface, but when you look a little closer at what they are talking about, you really begin to see how insignificant many of these agencies actually are. CN (West Indies) Steamship Limited is a good example. Apparently it hardly exists except on paper. I ask then, how can the government "wind up" something that actually wound up a long time ago and then go back to the Canadian people and tell them about the government's great efforts toward privatization.
The real question should be this, why is CN (West Indies) Steamship Limited still on the books in the first place? Are Canadians supposed to be impressed that after seven and one-half years the government has finally awakened to this fact. I think not. I am quite sure Canadians see through this transparent budget and the veil of responsiveness to the Canadian people, but unfortunately, a veil only.
To conclude, let me say this. The government has promised spending reductions. In reality, we have seen spending increases. The national debt is now approaching half a trillion dollars, as I mentioned, and this budget does almost nothing to deal with it. The government says: "We are cutting $1 billion.".
Neither has this government done anything to actually stimulate the economy. The best it could come up with unfortunately is a half-baked scheme for a limited
March 11, 1992

number of people to use their RRSP money for buying a house.
Unfortunately, this budget provides no leadership whatsoever and that is what Canadians are crying out for more than anything else. Perhaps the government would now consider seriously stepping aside so that real leadership may be gained and the people of Canada given a budget that they can actually live with and be given some optimism as we move towards the 21st century.

speakerposition: Minister of Agriculture
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I note my hon. colleague's suggestion that leadership should be given. I listened intently through the whole 10 minutes of my colleague's address. I did not hear one suggestion where reductions should take place.
I did not hear a criticism in specifics to the increase in government expenditures in agriculture. I know her party's policy is an over-all reduction of 15 per cent of all government expenditures instead of an increase in agriculture and instead of an increase in child benefits of some $400 million, which she criticized. I would like to ask her what she would have cut to address that $400 million. What would she would have reduced beyond the 15 per cent to have an increase in agriculture, an increase in the other expenditures to make up for the reduction in government income with lowering taxes. That has to be a benefit to the people of Canada.
The other thing I would ask the hon. member is if she could identify what her party would have cut and what her party would have put forward if it had the opportunity to lead.
I know her leader has turned down six invitations to appear before the Standing Committee of Finance to explain this presto magic that he is prepared to work for the Canadian public. I will sit down now, Madam Speaker, and allow the member ample time to explain the cuts that the Reform Party would put in place in old age pensions, old age security and assistance to agriculture and other economic forces in the country.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, without sounding facetious, I think as we look through these budget papers, I would recommend probably that the very first place the hon. Minister of Agriculture could make a very significant cut, not simply a 5 per cent cut, would be to his ministerial salary. That is to take place on April 1.
The Budget
The budget also said that the government would cancel all first class travel seats for members of Parliament and senators. I understand from some of the airline companies that most of those first class seats are actually being taken out on all domestic flights.
I think that is probably a good place to start. I am not sure whether there are first class seats any more on flights back and forth to Saskatchewan. I have not seen any for a very long time on aeroplanes moving in and out of Alberta at any rate.
Those are the types of things that people in the Canadian public are looking at. He asked me about specific places where we can cut. There will be nothing in our blue book that will say there will be 15 per cent cuts across the board. This minister unfortunately is going around the country saying: "There we are. The Reform Party is going to take grocery money away of seniors. It is going to cut hospital beds" Nothing is further from the truth.
In areas especially with agriculture that this minister asks specifically about, we believe agricultural input costs must be lowered. We are talking about lower interest rates. I give this government credit that it has gone down somewhat. There is still a fair spread. We are looking at somehow coming up with negotiations with the GATT that we do not necessarily need to be talking about domestic agricultural policies when we are at the GATT negotiations. We are looking forward to seeing what this government is really going to do at the GATT negotiations rather than flying from Mexico over to Europe and saying: "This is how we are going to address this problem".
We believe that this federal government also specifically could get rid of many Crown corporations. Again, this has been a start in this budget. When we are still running a $27.5 billion debt in this country, it is simply not good enough.
The Canadian public wants equality of sacrifice across the country in the agricultural sector as well as in the public sector, as well as people in the private sector. I am a teacher by trade and I know that many teachers whom I speak with would stand up in this Chamber if they were here with me and say: "I would take a cut across the board if I knew that every single Canadian, if every

The Budget
sector in Canada were to say that they are serious enough about this debt situation".

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Oh, oh.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
These people may laugh, but I belong to a teaching union. Unfortunately here we are having a problem, but I believe that every sector if they were hit could write on note paper: "We are willing to take a cut right across the board so that there would be equality of sacrifice in every sector of Canadian society". Those are some specifics. I know that the agricultural community needs to deal with this.
We are looking forward in the long term. Farmers are not keen about subsidies. They do not want government handouts. What we do want to make sure is that we are able to see equality of sacrifice in every sector in society. It is unfortunate that I hear the hoopla from the agriculture minister.
